NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Beauval Ind. Res. School for the Quarter ended Dec. 31 1949

P.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal

Dated Jan. 3 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

MEADOW LAKE INDIAN AGENCY

Dated at this 1950

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Sir,

I duly received your letter, number and date as given above, also the enclosure the same being the copy of a letter to Rev'd. Brother Gautier, all with reference to the purchase of certain materials for Beauval Indian Boarding School.

The Rev'd. Brother Gautier called at my office in the afternoon of the 3rd instant, and he handed me the list of said materials.

I immediately got busy on the lists in order to get competitive prices. I specified that these prices should be in my hands by noon of the 6th instant, and they were. I then figured them and made an abstract to find out who were the successful parties. I then got Rev'd. Brother Gautier to look over some lines in order that he would be satisfied with the quality, as soon as this was completed I placed the orders on the morning of the 8th instant for immediate shipment.

I had just made inquiry this morning when the goods would be shipped and was informed that the paints were all ready, I told them to ship at once. The other materials will be ready today and will be shipped tomorrow the 12th inst.

I have kept right after these orders as I was aware of the difficulties of transportation that might arise at this time of the year.

I have the honor to be,

your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Jones & Moore Electric Co., Toronto, re a Generator bought by the Department for our School and asking me to certify the invoice "correct" and forward to the Department. Before doing so I want to explain the facts about that Generator.

The Generator ordered by the Dep. was a 125 volts Generator - And the invoice shows, 125 volts also. Now the Generator they sent here was marked 110 volts and the only instructions sent with same was a diagram marked also "110 volts Generator". Then I took advice from electricians and was told that this Generator would not do for our motor which is 125 volts as well as for our lamps which are 125 volts also. I was told too that it would be dangerous to raise the voltage of a 110 volts Generator to 125 volts by accelerating the speed as the machine would be overcharged. Consequently as it was late in the season it was the last chance I had to send the Generator back on account of bad roads I returned it to Jones & Moore Co., explaining their mistake of 110 volts.

These Gentlemen stooped the Generator in Winnipeg claiming that this Generator was specially built and could be raised to 125 volts by accelerating the speed without any danger for the Machine, and acknowledged "that" the Generator was marked 110 by "Mistake". Why did they not explain this when they sent the Generator, if they had I would not have returned it. But as I received no instructions, I could not possibly undertake to put it into use, on a 125 voltage, how these Gentlemen expect me to pay the freight occasioned by their mistake. The best I can do is to pay the freight from Big River to Beauval and back-

over.
But I think that it would only fair to make them pay the freight on the railroad, at least, as the mistake is all at their account. Just now I cannot say if the Generator is still in Winnipeg or if it has been sent to Big River. Hoping you will use your influence to settle this case in the right way—and thanking you in anticipation.

I remain

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Re Basement

It is proposed to have no basement in the building and to build at ground level. Reasons given:

(a) Almost impossible to keep basement clean - the wind brings in so much dust.
(b) Basements, in these regions, are unsanitary, being always cold and moist. The case at Sturgeon Landing.
(c) The appearance of the house would be improved if the building were made some seven or eight feet higher.
(d) If the recreation halls were placed on ground level, they could be made to open on spacious verandahs which would be most useful.
(e) The cost of the building would be reduced by the suppression of the basement. The digging is very expensive, having to be done entirely by hand shovel.

The foregoing suggestions of Father Adam are approved by Mgr. Charlebois.

Mgr. Charlebois would like to have an early answer to the following questions:
(a) Is it the opinion of the Department that we should build of brick? If so, of brick veneer or of solid brick?
(b) Can we suppress the basement and build at ground level?

Mgr. Charlebois hopes that a bonus of $25,000 may be granted him (to be put in the fall estimates) to cover in part the expenses to be made next summer in the building of a portion of the School at Beauval.

MEMO

concerning the construction of the Beauval Indian School,

from Father Adam.

Re brick-making

Samples of clays from Beauval have been tested in the laboratories of the University of Saskatoon. In the report, which was sent to Rev. Father M. Lajeunesse of Le Pas, the following lines appear: "The clays here reported are among the best that have passed through these laboratories for testing as building brick clays.

The cost of making the bricks, according to the report, would not exceed $12 per thousand, allowing $3 a day for the laborers and $5.50 for a cord of wood.

The number of bricks required would be about 400,000 for the exterior of the whole building and the baking ovens.

The total cost of making the bricks would therefore be about $2,500. This number must be multiplied by 3 if the walls are to be of solid brick, so that the cost in this case would be $8,400.

The cost of making the bricks at Beauval would be much lower than that at which they could be bought at the nearest prairie brick-yard.

In order that the new school may be as nearly fireproof as possible, it is proposed to build the walls of solid brick. The plans should be made accordingly. The air-space in the walls not to be forgotten.

According to the report from the University of Saskatoon, the cost of the machinery for brick-making would be about $2,000. The machine which we intend to buy is of medium size, weighs 1600 lbs., can make 10,000 bricks per day, can be worked by an 8 H.P. motor, and can mould drain tiles as well as bricks.

Re Reconstruction of School

It is proposed to build, for the first year, only the central portion of the school and the part behind it which contains the chapel. Reasons given for this proposal:

1.- The work could then be done mostly by the lay-brothers of the school aided by laborers who could be hired at Beauval. The cost of building would thus be materially reduced.

2.- If less work is undertaken at one time, more attention can be paid to the quality of the work.

3.- The Department of Indian Affairs would probably be more disposed to help us by annual grants covering a number of years than by a single heavy disbursement.

4.- The portion of the school which we intend to build would easily accommodate the staff of sisters and 50 Indian girls (the number which we had in the past years). For a number of years the recruiting of boys will be very hard, so many of the boys we had having died in the disastrous fire. If the whole building is put up at one time, a whole wing of it would be useless for some years.

Memorandum: Dr. Scott.

Plans and specifications have been prepared for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Beauval. The plans provide accommodation for 75 pupils. The building will be constructed of brick manufactured on the premises and heated with a low pressure steam heating system. A complete sewerage system will be installed and all modern plumbing fixtures throughout the building. An electric lighting plant will be provided to furnish the necessary power to light the building. The cost of the building will be approximately $100,000 if erected at a reasonable distance from railway transportation.

In view of the fact that a large quantity of the materials required will have to be transported from Big River, it is difficult to state definitely what the cost of the building will be erected at Beauval. Part of the cost of transportation will be offset as the Church authorities are manufacturing their own brick at Beauval and also can supply all of the rough lumber required from their own saw mills at this point.

The most economical way of having the building constructed is by day labour under the supervision of the Church authorities, more especially as they are in a position to supply a large quantity of the materials directly on the site. They will also be able to arrange more economical transportation for supplies brought in from Big River.

Ottawa, May 21, 1939.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that the main building at the Beauval Indian Residential School, near Lac la Plonge, in the Province of Saskatchewan, was destroyed by fire in September, 1937. The Oblate Order, under whose auspices this school is being conducted, has offered to erect a new building, provided the department will give a grant of $80,000.00 towards the cost.

An amount of $25,000.00 has been included in the Main Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1939/30, and it is proposed to include a similar amount in the Estimates for 1939/30, for this purpose.

Plans and specifications for the proposed building have been prepared by the department. Accommodation for seventy-five pupils is provided.

The building is to be constructed of brick manufactured on the premises and heated with a low pressure steam heating system. A complete sewerage system is to be installed and all modern plumbing fixtures throughout the building. An electric lighting plant is to be provided to furnish the necessary power to light the premises.

In the opinion of the Architect of the department the cost of the building would be approximately $100,000.00 if erected at a reasonable distance from railway transportation.

In view of the fact that a large quantity of the materials required would have to be transported from the railway line at Big River, a distance of 113 miles, it is difficult to state definitely what the cost of the building will be erected at Beauval. Part of the cost of transportation would be offset by the Church authorities manufacturing their own brick at Beauval and also can supply all the rough lumber required from their own saw mills at this point. It follows, however, that the proposed expenditure by the department represents not more than one moiety of the total cost.
In view of the remoteness of the locality it appears inexpedient to call for tenders. It is considered that the most economical way of having the building constructed is by day labour under the supervision of the Church authorities, more especially as they are in a position to supply a large quantity of the materials directly on the site. They will also be able to arrange more economical transportation for supplies bought in from Big River.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that the proposed grant to be expended in the manner aforesaid be approved.

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find duplicate receipts covering further expenditure in connection with the replacement of Beauval Indian Residential School. As you will notice, most of these expenditures are for transportation from Big River to Beauval.

Freight.

I may say that this freighting was done at a very fair price. For the 128 miles which separate Big River from Beauval we paid $1.20 and $1.35 per cwt., while here we pay $1.75 per cwt. for freighting to Sturgeon Landing, a distance of not quite fifty miles.

Bonus.

In connection with the freighting, you will notice that a bonus of $63.65 has been given to Mr Fortin. This was occasioned by the fact that the heating plant and plumbing supplies did not arrive until February so that the greater portion of it could not be freighted during the fishing season. The fishing season being over, the teams were freighting only one way, so that no one would undertake to carry freight to Beauval for the $1.35 paid by the Big River Consolidated Fisheries. This is why we had to give a bonus to Mr A. Fortin on the goods conveyed to Beauval after the fishing season. Our bonus was very conservative and we are confident that Mr Fortin made no money on that freight.
Wages Paid.

I beg to give a few explanations in regard to statement of wages paid: Wages shown on Sheets 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 are for work done last Fall for digging the foundations. Wages shown on sheets 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 16 and part of 17, and for work done in loading and hauling gravel and sand from Lac la Plonge. As there is no sand or gravel available around the Mission, it was easier and more economical to haul it on the Winter Roads than to wait for the opening of navigation.

The last three items on Sheet 17 refer to the erection of a temporary building required for the construction.

Brick Plant.

You will be glad to hear that our brick plant is in operation and gives hope of full success. We learn from the last letter received, that they were making an average of ten thousand bricks a day. No bricks have been burned yet, but Mr Phillips, who is in charge of the brick plant, and who has been in that line for years, has no doubt as to the result of the burning. He claims that the clay is of the best quality.

Other work done.

The sewers are now completed and water pipes to the new building laid in the ground. They are commencing the cement work on the part to be erected this year.

Our good Mr Waddy will be at Beauval in a few days and we have no doubt he will be satisfied with the work being done there.

Yours very truly,

Martin Lajeunesse

Isle a la Crosse, June 17th, 1929.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report as follows on my visit to the Beauval Indian Residential School on the 14th and 15th inst.

You probably are familiar with the arrangements regarding building the new school here. I understand it is being built by the church authorities under arrangement with the Department. The rear wing of the new school is to be built this year; all material for the heating, electric fixtures, water system is on hand, also the sand, gravel, cement, lime, lumber etc. The basement is excavated, footings of brick laid, floors up for the basement walls. The whole school is to have solid brick walls, all the brick being made within a hundred yards of the school site. Last winter a brick making machine was brought in from Prince Albert with a steam engine to supply the power. The staff used over 40,000 f.b.m. of lumber to construct the drying racks for the bricks, making sheds etc., and they have the plant in running order now. In the few days it has been operating they have made 75,000 bricks and they were turning out thirty bricks a minute when I was there; on Friday they made over 13,000. After the brick dries for a week a kiln is made and the brick burnt for three days. It is expected that 800,000 will be required. A first class bookkeeper is on the job and he keeps track of every item entering into the construction of the school, keeps a time of the men etc. He was watching the cost of the brick making very closely, and including overhead, cost of machines, transport of same, etc time of expert brick maker, steam engineer and all labor he was down to $20.00 per thousand and is trying to cut this down.

J. W. Waddy,
Paying Agent.
Sir:

There is a set of batteries at the Indian Residential school at Lebret which I thought would be of service at the Indian School at Beauval, Sask. As you are aware the former institution is supplied with light and power by the Montreal Engineering Company, and the Department has gone to some considerable expenditure in providing new equipment to meet the changed conditions.

When suggesting the transfer of these batteries to Beauval, the Reverend Father Leonard demurred and appears desirous of retaining them, notwithstanding that I have pointed out that they would only be required in case of a break-down, and, while lying idle for such an emergency, would deteriorate rapidly and become useless. They would be of greater service at Beauval, and I would ask the Department's authority to have them transferred to that point immediately.

I have just received a telegram from the Reverend Principal at Beauval asking me to have them re-charged and over-hauled, and have them sent to Beauval by the first proximo. It would be appreciated if you would telegraph your authority.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

re Brick Plant.

LE PAS, May. October 28th, 1929.

Mr. D. Scott, Deputy Minister,
Departement of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I was somewhat surprised to hear, through Fr M.
Lajeunesse, who has lately interviewed you, that the Depart-
ment of Indian Affairs was under the impression that I
have undertaken to rebuild the Beauval Indian School provided
a grant of $50,000 would be given, and that an Order in
Council had been passed to this effect.

When the question of rebuilding the Beauval School
was first discussed with the Department, and when the useful-
ness of that School was doubted, I may have hinted that a
grant of $50,000 would probably be sufficient to enable us
to rebuild the school, having in mind at that time that a
frame building, and one of small dimensions, was to be erected.
I am pretty sure that, as far as I am concerned, there are no
official documents showing that there was a definite agree-
ment in the matter. My personal impression, after my interview
with you, was that the Department did not deem it wise to call
publicly for tenders. I understood also that, in order to elude
the attention of profiteers, the Department would grant only
a part of the money for the first and the second year, but
would eventually refund all the money expended in the construc-
tion of the School. It was in this sense that I understood
the letter in which you advised me that an initial grant of
$25,000 had been voted for this year, and that a similar grant would be given next year. It never occurred to me that no further grants would be given by the Department for this enterprise.

I was further confirmed in my opinion by the fact that we were advised to follow, in the construction of the School, the plans which would be prepared for us by your Department. This appeared to me as an evident proof that your Department was to take full possession of the Beauval School and to pay all the expenses of construction.

I understand quite well that religious denominations must take a share in the education of the Indians, and I would like to remark that our share in the education of the Indians of the Île-à-la-Crosse region has been very generous indeed. For nearly half a century the Grey Nuns have kept an Indian School there without any substantial remuneration. It was only when the school was transferred from Île-à-la-Crosse to Beauval that the grant per capita was given. The first school at Beauval was built without any assistance from the Department, and for over twenty years it has carried on the same work as the schools of the Department. The chief help which the old Beauval School obtained from the Department was the grant per capita, but it should not be forgotten that, according to experts in that field of education, this grant covers only about 70% of the expenses of a residential school.

As for the construction of the new School, we are ready to help as far as our means will permit. Is it not a great advantage for the Department to be assured that, through our
co-operation, all monies granted will be spent with the greatest economy, and that every cent of them will enter into the very structure of the building? No charge is made for travelling expenses and for the work incurred in the buying of the materials, for telegrams, for bookkeeping charges, and for the supervision of the work and of the transportation.

In the interview which you granted Fathers A. and M. La-jeunesse, my representatives, you stated that a further grant for the reconstruction of the Beauval School could not be voted before the acquisition by the Department of the land on which the School is being erected. This is a very reasonable objection, but I think that the matter can be very easily settled. As the land concerned is not yet surveyed, it is impossible to give titles for it, but I am willing to transfer to the Dept. our rights to:

1.- All the land on the north side of the Laplonge river up to the reserve, of which about twenty acres are under cultivation.

2.- The following buildings now standing on that land: one large house for the male staff, a cow-stable, a horse-stable, a pig-house, a poultry-house, a root-house, three small houses for labourers, a grainary, and sheds.

3.- All the agricultural implements: plows, harrows, binder, thresher, tractor, potato-planter, potato-digger, manure-spreader, wagons, &c.

Let me now state frankly what I expect from the Department of Indian Affairs.

Mr. Orr estimates that the construction of the Beauval School according to the plans furnished by him will cost all
of $100,000, supposing that the school is not very far from a railway line. Now, Beauval is at a distance of 120 miles from Big River, the nearest station, and it is known that the transportation of certain necessary material, cement for instance, costs more than the material itself.

We have also made a detailed estimate of the total cost, taking as a basis of our calculation the cost of the part of the building which was put up last summer. As the sum of $29,000 which we have received from the Department this year has covered only a part of the expenses made, we also come to the conclusion that $100,000 more would be needed to cover the total cost of the construction. I would therefore ask the Department:

1.- To bear all the expenses in the reconstruction of the Beauval School;

2.- To give for next year a grant of not less than $75,000 to allow us to continue the construction of the School next summer.

I regret to say that if the Department does not see its way to grant my request, the construction work will have to be interrupted and postponed for an indefinite period. This, I think, would be a misfortune for this part of the country, for the Beauval School has done good work in the past and it gives great hopes for the future.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Mr Scott,

Pursuant to your communication of November 22nd, 1929 (File 132-1-5), I am glad to hear that $25,000.00 has been placed in the Main Estimates towards the reconstruction of the Beauval Indian Residential School. But as I have already informed you in my letter of October 28th., this amount is not enough to allow us to continue the construction.

We have already advanced the money to cut and manufacture the lumber for the whole building as well as to install the brick plant and manufacture the brick which has been used in the part already erected. None of this money (which amounts to a large sum) has been refunded. Moreover, wages for the part erected last Summer have been refunded only up to August 3rd, 1929, leaving a large balance which we had to cover. Besides this, the inside of this part is not finished, the plaster has yet to be purchased, freighted and put on, etc. This means that the $25,000.00 will be exhausted when all this will be finished.

In these circumstances we are obliged to stop the work until further assistance can be obtained. We have tried to raise the money necessary at least to buy and freight...
the balance of the material during the freighting season,
but this is beyond our means, and with great regret we shall
be obliged to let things lie until we can obtain further
assistance.

No need to tell you that the fact of not being able
to buy and freight the balance of the material this winter
will have serious consequences, because transportation by
boat is very expensive and sometimes is not possible when the
water is too low.

May I also mention that if the work is not resumed
next Summer the school will not be open before 1932, leaving
the children of all the Ile-a-la-Crosse District without
education as there is no day-school in that part of the
country. We shall also be obliged, for the same reason,
to dismiss a crew of good bricklayers and carpenters who
are ready to keep on working for very low wages.

I understand that it is not in your power to do
more at the present time, but as I can rely on your sympathy,
I feel it advisable to tell you about our difficulties in
regard to this construction.

Yours very sincerely,

April 28, 1930.

Dear Father Adam,

I have your letter of the 14th also sample of sand and would make the following suggestion:

Sample No 1 and Sample No 2 will be quite satisfactory for plastering or mortar for brick work, providing it is passed over a 1/20" screen which has a No 14 mesh.

Sample No 3 and 4 will be satisfactory for concrete work and for economical use it will require a quantity of coarser gravel added.

Sample No 5, which is pure sand, would of course be satisfactory for plaster or mortar without screening.

It would therefore appear that it will be more economical to use No 1 and 2 screened for plaster or mortar in place of No 5.

Trusting that this information is what you require I remain,

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

May 5, 1930

Mr. Duncan Scott,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We were much pleased to hear, in the course of the interview which we had with you on May the 3rd, that you were in favor of raising from its ashes the Indian Residential School of Cross-Lake and of going on with the construction of the Beauval School. Your kind words have relieved us from many of the sorrows and cares which have assailed us since the sad fires which have destroyed so many lives and so much valuable property.

Your decision of constructing no other but fireproof buildings for Indian Residential Schools is highly commendable for its wisdom and prudence. The recurrence of such calamities as have taken place in the past is to be prevented by all means possible.

We understand that, for this year, no substantial funds for building purposes can be relied upon. However, we should like to have your directions concerning the work which we might do this summer as a preparation for the building operations of next year.

We would suggest that an expert be sent to examine the walls of the burned school at Cross-Lake in order to determine whether they can be used in a new building. As far as I could judge, these walls are still in a fairly good condition, and, as the stress in a fireproof building is not so much on the walls as on the inside pillars, I am inclined to think that they might be used to advantage. This of course would save much time and much expense.

Acting in accordance with verbal instructions received from your Department, we have made preparations, in the course of winter, for continuing the construction of the Beauval School during this summer. Four car-loads of cement and all the steel necessary for the reinforced concrete have been bought and carted from Big River to Beauval. We find now that, on account of the lack of funds, we will be unable to go on with the construction of the whole school. But, considering that cement deteriorates rapidly in the moist atmosphere of this region, we would suggest that the plans for the new fireproof building to be erected at Beauval be draughted by the architect of your Department as soon as possible, and that a sufficient appropriation be granted us to allow us to build
these foundations in the course of the present summer, using for that purpose the cement and the steel we have now on hand.

May we also suggest that, as the new building at Beauval is to be fireproof, its ground dimensions might be made smaller, and a third story added to it. This would lessen the cost of the foundations and of the roof; while, in a fireproof building, there would be no objection in having the dormitories on the third floor.

Hoping that the above suggestions will be found acceptable,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

+ O. Charlebois, O.S.B.
Bishop of Keewatin

[Handwritten note:]
He would doubtless like to know what added (footings foundation) materials should be taken into account, in view of fireproof construction.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSHNELL,

With reference to the subject matter of Mr. Olsen's letter, which is enclosed, I may say that the main building of the Beauval Indian Residential School, near Lac la Plonge, Saskatchewan, was destroyed by fire in September, 1927. Bishop Charlebois, of the Pas, representing the Oblate Order, offered to rebuild, if the Department would give a grant of $50,000 towards the cost. The Department accepted this proposal, which was approved by P.C. 932, of May 30th, 1929 - the new building to be erected by the Order on a day labour basis. During the past year and a half, this grant of $50,000 has been paid.

A year ago, His Lordship intimated that there was a misunderstanding regarding the financing and, in June, last, he stated that the Oblate Order could not complete the programme without more assistance. I may say that the Department Architect estimated the cost of the building at over $100,000. Bishop Charlebois stated that the building could not be completed unless the Department assumed the entire cost, involving an additional $75,000. In June, he was informed that no further funds were available this year and that, before anything could be done in 1931 or later, the money would have to be voted by Parliament and additional authority from His Excellency in Council secured.

Owing to the present condition of the Appropriation for Indian Education and the desirability of giving the Minister an opportunity to review the whole situation before deciding the future programme or allowing any extensions, it is not yet timely to make any promise in connection with the future building programme.

I know it is desirable to have freighting to Lac la Plonge done during the winter time, but I have to recommend to the Minister that his correspondent be informed that, as yet, there has been no decision concerning the completion of the Beauval School.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 30th MAY 1929.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 21st May, 1929, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, stating that the main building at the Beauval Indian Residential School, near Lac la Plonge, in the Province of Saskatchewan, was destroyed by fire in September, 1927. The Oblate Order, under whose auspices this school is being conducted, has offered to erect a new building, provided the department will give a grant of $50,000 towards the cost.

An amount of $25,000 has been included in the Main Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1929/30, and it is proposed to include a similar amount in the Estimates for 1930/31, for this purpose.

Plans and specifications for the proposed building have been prepared by the department. Accommodation for seventy-five pupils is provided.

The building is to be constructed of brick manufactured on the premises and heated with a low pressure steam heating system. A complete sewerage system is to be installed and all modern plumbing fixtures throughout the building. An electric lighting plant is to be provided to furnish the necessary power to light the premises.

The Honourable

In

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
In the opinion of the Architect of the department the cost of the building would be approximately $100,000 if erected at a reasonable distance from railway transportation.

In view of the fact that a large quantity of the materials required would have to be transported from the railway line at Big River, a distance of 112 miles, it is difficult to state definitely what the cost of the building will be erected at Beauval. Part of the cost of transportation would be offset as the Church authorities are manufacturing their own brick at Beauval and also can supply all the rough lumber required from their own saw mills at this point. It follows, however, that the proposed expenditure by the department represents not more than one moiety of the total cost.

Owing to the remoteness of the locality it appears inexpedient to call for tenders. It is considered that the most economical way of having the building constructed is by day labour under the supervision of the Church authorities, more especially as they are in a position to supply a large quantity of the materials directly on the site. They will also be able to arrange a more economical transportation for supplies brought in from Big River.

The Minister recommends that the proposed grant be expended in the manner aforesaid.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

With reference to the subject matter of Mr. Olsen's letter, which is enclosed, I may say that the main building of the Beauval Indian Residential School near Lac la Plonge, Saskatchewan, was destroyed by fire in September, 1927. Bishop Charlebois, of The Pas, representing the Oblate Order, offered to rebuild, if the Department would give a grant of $50,000 towards the cost. The Department accepted this proposal, which was approved by P.C. 932, of May 30th, 1929 - the new building to be erected by the Order on a day labour basis. During the past year and a half, this grant of $50,000 has been paid.

A year ago, His Lordship intimated that there was a misunderstanding regarding the financing and, in June, last, he stated that the Oblate Order could not complete the programme without more assistance. I may say that the Department architect estimated the cost of the building at over $100,000. Bishop Charlebois stated that the building could not be completed unless the Department assume the entire cost, involving an additional $75,000. In June, he was informed that no further funds were available this year and that, before anything could be done in 1931 or later, the money would have to be voted by Parliament and additional authority from His Excellency in Council secured.

Owing to the present condition of the Appropriation for Indian Education and the desirability of giving the Minister an opportunity to review the whole situation before deciding the future programme or allowing any extensions, it is not yet timely to make any promise in connection with the future building programme.

I know it is desirable to have freighting to Lac la Plonge done during the winter time, but I have to recommend to the Minister that his correspondent be informed that, as yet, there has been no decision concerning the completion of the Beauval School.

Duncan C. Scott

Inspector Murison's Report on the Schools in the Ile a la Crosse Agency:

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools in the Ile a la Crosse Agency, which I inspected during my visit to that Agency when making the annuity payments this year.

BEAUVAL SCHOOL:

I visited this school on June the 15th last, and made a general inspection of the buildings, and visited the class-rooms.

Since this school was burned down a few years ago, they have had very little accommodation for pupils, and only 18 girls are kept in residence.

The staff includes Rev. F. X. Gagnon, as Principal, Brother Beaudion, Carpenter and Engineer, Brother August Duclos as Farmer, and Brother Coulais as general helper. He also has as assistants six sisters of Charity. They include a Superior, Teacher, Nurse, Cook, Girls' Matron and Seamstress.

I visited the class-rooms, and made a general examination. The pupils are divided into three grades, with four in Grade II, Five in Grade III, and nine in Grade IV. They speak up well, understand their work,

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, Sask.

and appear to be
and appear to be well up in their grades. The teacher is properly qualified, and has a Second Class Certificate for Saskatchewan. The pupils presented a healthy appearance. A room in the completed part of the new school is being temporarily used as a class-room.

Buildings:

A portion of the new school was completed last year, and the work impressed me as being very well done. The completed wing is 35 feet X 70 feet, and provides in the basement a kitchen, laundry, engine-room, boiler-room, bakery, dairy, machine-room, drier, men's dining room, store-room, fuel-room, bathroom and engineer's room. The upstairs provides a chapel which has been completed.

During the past winter, cement and lime were hauled in, but as no money was provided this year, and as the cement and lime would have deteriorated and many hundreds of dollars wasted, the church authorities, in order to safeguard the work already done, and to save this material, engaged a foreman and the necessary workmen, and the work of building the main building was well under way at the time of my visit. I understand that, at the present time, the building is all ready for the roof and I expect that the roof will be completed shortly. I understood from the Principal that it was not the intention to finish the building this year, but simply to close it in, so that the work already done may be protected.

The walls are of
The walls are of brick, which was made on the ground. Brick-making machinery was provided for this purpose. The brick appears to be of very good quality.

The work is being performed by day labour. The foreman is a lay-brother, and there are five lay-brothers who are brought in from outside, working on the building. They include two carpenters, who receive $5.00 per day, and three brick-layers who receive $5.00 per day, $4.00 per day, and $3.50 per day respectively. Their transportation and expenses in are paid, and they get their board as well. Indians and Halfbreeds are engaged to perform the rough labour. Plumbing and Electrical work in the main building will be done by a lay-brother.

I was informed by the Reverend Principal, that at the time of my visit, they had expended $45,000.00 in excess of the amount advanced by the Department, and it was estimated that approximately $100,000.00 will be required to complete the building. In the meantime the Church is advancing the money to pay for material and labour to complete the walls and put the roof on, and they are naturally becoming very anxious to know when they may expect a refund from the Government of the amount expended. Of course they have done this on their own authority, but it appears to me to be good business, and their action will eventually affect a considerable saving in the ultimate cost of the building, as there would have been a considerable loss had they not used up

the cement and lime.
the cement and lime. I found this school a very interesting one to visit.

As you already know, some years ago they harnessed the La Plonge River, and all the power required for operating their sawmill, brick-making machinery and electrical lighting plant, is generated by a water turbine. The water supply is also obtained from the La Plonge River, and is pumped to the buildings with a hydraulic ram.

Their out-buildings include a cow barn, 32 feet X 100 feet, with a loft. This barn is equipped with Beatty Brothers iron fixtures, and there is running water accessible to each stall. They have a horse stable with accommodation for 17 horses, a root cellar, hen-house, pig-pen, warehouse and large cattle pasture.

Their livestock includes 65 cattle. Fifteen cows are milked regularly. The boys, when at school do the milking, under the supervision of the Brother. They informed me that they would commence teaching the girls to do this. Two brood sows are regularly kept, from which they obtain two litters per year, and they keep about 150 poultry.

Farm:

Twelve sections of land have been reserved for the use of a school, but has not been surveyed. The land comprises a large hay meadow which would provide sufficient hay for their requirements, as well as some farm land, most of which would have to be cleared. The soil is a light sandy loam. Ninety five acres are under cultivation, 65 acres of which

is in grain
is in grain crop this year.

They have a large and well-kept garden. Their farm last year produced 225 bushels of wheat, 1200 bushels of oats and 450 bushels of barley. The garden produced 2240 bushels of potatoes and other roots, and vegetables sufficient for their requirements.

The present principal, Father Gagnon, has only been recently appointed, but he impressed me as being a capable business man, active, energetic and interested in the welfare of his school.

The pupilage is obtained from Canoe Lake, English River, Clear Lake, Buffalo River and La Loche Lake. It is quite easy to get to English River, Clear Lake, and Buffalo River, as there are no portages, and plenty of water. These are the largest bands from which pupilage is obtained, and as they are from 50 to 100 miles from the school, the Principal has expressed the wish to have a large motor-boat to enable them to visit these points in any weather. Canoe Lake can be reached over land, and is about 30 miles distant.
Évêché, Le Pas, Man., le 7 novembre, 1931.

État de la construction de l'école de Beauval.

Mon Réverend Père,

Voici dans quel état se trouve l'école de Beauval vers le 15 décembre prochain:

L'extérieur sera complètement fini.

À l'intérieur, tous les murs du dehors seront bien plâtrés et il en sera ainsi des murs de séparation des dortoirs, des classes et des parloirs. Quant aux autres murs de séparation, faute de ciment, ils ne seront que blanchis avec une composition qui ne s'efface pas.

Le plancher du sous-sol est en bois de bouleau sec (birch) et repose sur une couche de pierres brisées d'un pied et demi. Le plancher du dortoir est aussi en bois qui recouvre la dalle de ciment. Les deux autres planchers sont simplement en ciment qu'on a poli le mieux possible.

Le système de chauffage est déjà fini.

Le système d'éclairage est également fini.

J'ai oublié de dire que les murs de séparation sont en briques.

Le réservoir pour l'eau est construit.

Le système d'égout est installé et le système d'eau sera complète, dans toute la bâtisse, pour le quinze décembre.

Le lavoir est pourvu de machines, même d'un sechoir "home made".

Nous n'avons pas acheté de portes pour les séparations intérieures, nous en fabriquerons en planches là où elles sont absolument nécessaires et nous attendrons l'aide du Dép. pour nous en procurer.

Il y a vingt lits tout montés. Si le Département ne peut pas nous fournir d'autres couchettes, nous en ferons en planches et les matelas...
seront remplacés par des paillasses de paille, ça suffira durant la crise. Il faudrait des couvertes, des draps et des oreillers pour cinquante lits au moins.

Pour la vaisselle, nous pourrons en acheter et débiter le Dép. comme pour tout le reste.

Pour les livres de classe, les pupitres et les tableaux, une liste sera envoyée plus tard, si on nous permet d'ouvrir. Cependant, pour les pupitres, nous pourrions faire des tables provisoires, si on le juge à propos. Nous ne voulons réclamer que le strict nécessaire.

Voici maintenant quelques explications au sujet de nos activités. Notre premier plan était de construire seulement la charpente de l'école et cela afin d'utiliser le ciment qui était acheté et rendu sur place. Après avoir fait la structure, nous avons pensé qu'il ne serait pas sage de laisser cette bâtisse ouverte à tous les vents. De plus on nous a dit que ce serait imprudent de laisser ainsi les dalles de ciments sans être appuyées par les murs de séparation. Or nous nous sommes dit: tant qu'à poser les châssis, tant qu'à faire les séparations intérieures, tant qu'à poser le système de chauffage, il vaut bien mieux finir le strict nécessaire afin de pouvoir nous servir de la bâtisse. Nous avons donc décidé de faire de nouveaux emprunts et de finir.

C'est ce qui explique pourquoi nous avons dépensé ce qui était mentionné dans le rapport d'octobre. Je crois que le Département ne nous blâmera pas, j'espère même qu'il trouvera que nous avons été bien sages. Le coût de la bâtisse ne sera certainement pas excessif. Nous avons fait tout notre possible pour épargner tout en faisant du bon travail. Je désire même que le Département envoie un inspecteur pour examiner les travaux, vers le quinze décembre. Cet ins-
pecteur pourra faire un rapport plus détaillé et désintéressé.

Le présent rapport est basé seulement sur les lettres que nous avons reçu dernièrement de Beauval. Je suis persuadé cependant qu'un inspecteur sera satisfait du travail.

Maintenant, nous pensons qu'il n'y aura pas de danger pour l'humidité, au mois de janvier prochain, au point de pouvoir nuire à la santé des enfants. Voici pourquoi : Les murs extérieurs et les épais planchers sont finis depuis la mi-septembre. Ils ont eu le temps de sécher, vu que les portes et les fenêtres étaient ouvertes. Les murs des séparations intérieures ne sont pas épais et sont finis depuis trois semaines. Ils ont dû sécher passablement. Au sous-sol, il ne peut y avoir d'humidité vu que le plancher est en bois. Il reste encore plus de deux mois avant que les enfants soient prêts à venir. Le tout aura le temps de sécher très bien dans une maison bien chauffée. Cependant, si la prudence l'exige, nous retarderons l'entrée des enfants.

Je suis très content de voir par votre lettre que le Dép. se propose, à la prochaine session, de présenter des estimées dans le but de nous rembourser. Cela me donne un peu de courage, car réellement, si on nous laissait sans remboursement, nous nous trouverions dans une position très critique. Nous espérons qu'il n'en sera pas ainsi. Nous comptons sur le "fair play" de M. Scott et de M. Ferrier.

Votre tout dévoué,

[Signature]

With regard to the Lac la Ronge School, it will be noted that the situation of this school is not by any means as favourable as that at Beauval, there being very little land under cultivation, or fit for that purpose. Dear Father Marcotte:

Pursuant to our conversation this morning, I write to inform you that the Department would like to have a report concerning the progress at the Beauval Indian Residential School. Your intimation, that His Lordship Bishop Charlebois was hoping to admit pupils in January, comes as a surprise. The last information on our files suggests that the building was ready for the roof in October and that it was not the intention to do the interior finishing this year.

To plaster and finish the building and to have it ready for pupils should not be hurried, as it would be unsafe to have children sleeping in dormitories unless everything had been thoroughly dried out. Further, there is the matter of proper furnishing. As His Lordship understands, the Department has no funds to assist this year, and, before we can consider per capita grant, it will be necessary to have a full report concerning the preparations that are being made.

Re: State of construction of Beausoleil school

Respected Father,

The following is a description of the state in which the Beausoleil School will be by the 15th of December next.

The exterior will be completely finished.
At the interior all the outside walls will be well plastered and it will be the same with the separation walls of the dormitory, of the classrooms and the parlors. As to the other walls of separation, on account of lack of cement, they will only be whitewashed with a composition which does not come off.

The floor of the basement is of dry brick and is laid on a layer of broken stones one foot and a half thick. The floor of the dormitory is also of wood over the cement, while the other two floors are simply of cement which has been polished as well as possible.

The heating system is already completed.
The lighting system is also finished.
I forget to say that the partition walls are of bricks.

The water reservoir is built.
The sewer system is installed and the water system will be completed through the whole building for the 15th of December.
The laundry is provided with machinery, even a homemade dryer.
We did not purchase any doors for the inside.
partitions, we shall make some with lumber where they will be absolutely necessary and we will wait for the Department's help to get proper ones. There are twenty beds completely fitted. If the Department cannot supply us with more beds we will make some with boards and the mattresses will be replaced by straw mattresses which will have to do during the crisis. We will need blankets, sheets and pillows for fifty beds at least.

For the crockery we could purchase some and debit the Department the same as for everything else.

For the school books, desks and blackboards a list will be forwarded later on if we are permitted to open. However, for the desks, we could build temporary tables if it is judged proper. We only want to ask for what is strictly necessary.

It follows now some explanation concerning our activities. Our first plan was to construct only the frame of the school and that so as to utilize the cement which was bought and delivered on the premises. After the structure was up, we thought it would not be wise to leave the building open to all wind. Furthermore we were informed that it would be unwise to leave the cement floors without being sustained by partition walls. We consequently thought that if we had to put in the windows and make the repairs to the interior walls, and also fix the heating system, we were as well to complete what was strictly necessary so as to make use of the building. We therefore decide...
To borrow money and complete the work.

This is what explains the reason why we went over what was mentioned in the October report. I believe the Department will not blame us. We hope that they will find that we have acted wisely. The cost of the building will certainly not be excessive. We have done our very best to economize while we did good work. I wish the Department would send an inspector to examine the work about the 15th of December. That inspector could make a more detailed and disinterested report. The present report is solely based on letters we have received lately from Recruits. I am however convinced that an inspector will be satisfied of the work.

Now we think there will be no danger from dampness during January next, in a way to inconvenience the health of the children. This is why: The exterior walls and the brick floor were finished since the middle of September. They had the time to dry up as the doors and windows were kept open. The interior walls are not thick and were completed 2 weeks ago. They must be fairly dry. In the basement there can't be any dampness as the floor is of wood. There is still two months ahead before the children are ready to come. Everything will have time to dry well in a well heated house. However if it is safer, we will keep the entrance of the children.

I am very glad to see by your letter that the Dept. intends at the next session to present estimates to recoup us. This gives me much courage, because really if
if we were left without any refund, we would be in a very critical position. We hope it will not be so. We rely on the fair play of Mr. Scott and of Mr. Lefebvre.

Yours devotedly,

(Signed) +P. Charlebois, O.M.I.

November 16, 1931.

Dear Bishop Charlebois:

Reverend Father Marcotte, O.M.I., has handed to me Your Lordship's letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the situation at the Beauval Indian Residential School. I believe you have done wisely to complete the building while you had a staff of workers and some of the materials on the site. On the other hand, I feel that, from even the Church standpoint, Your Lordship would be making a mistake if you hurried the opening of the school. Do you not think it advisable to have the building properly finished and equipped and then offer it for inspection in July or August, when you could have the Indians you are serving come for a gala opening.

We are now considering the Estimates for the coming fiscal year, and I will present your claims in connection with Beauval to the Honourable the Superintendent General. There is, first, the question of reimbursement for this year's expenditure, and, further, provision for next year and the future. I will ask for per capita grant and for sufficient funds to finish the building and to furnish it. I should be pleased if Your Lordship would inform the Department immediately concerning the total expenditure you have incurred this year and indicate what should be done next spring to finish the building. You should also prepare a list of the furnishings that are required. This information is required in connection with the preparation of our Estimates.

I do not consider that to delay the opening for a few months is at all serious, when one remembers that the Indians the school serves earn their livelihood largely by hunting. The extra 6 months' education that the present generation of children would receive by hurrying the opening would be of little consequence. Far better to have everything properly prepared and to commence the second phase of this school's activity with the type of opening which proved so successful and popular in the case of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.
November 19, 1931.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY,

In connection with the preparation of Estimates and in order to reply to a recent letter from His Lordship Bishop Charlebois, of The Pas, Man., it is now necessary to decide what further help will be given for the new building at the Residential School, in northern Saskatchewan. In September, 1927, the old building was destroyed by fire, and Bishop Charlebois, representing the Oblate Order offered to rebuild if the Department would give a grant of $50,000. The Department accepted this proposal, which was approved by P.C. 932, of May 30, 1929 - a copy of which is attached. The new building was to be erected by the Order, on a day labour basis. During the year commencing June, 1929, this grant of $50,000 was paid.

In October, 1929, His Lordship intimated that there was a misunderstanding regarding financing and that the Oblate Order would require considerably more than the $50,000 if the building programme was to be completed. It appeared thought our assistance with plans and specifications announced that the Department was prepared to finance the entire undertaking. I wrote His Lordship that I was unable to state whether or not extra help could be given. Approximately $63,000 was expended by the Church authorities during 1929. Early in 1930, His Lordship, hoping that the Department would be able to make an additional grant, arranged for the freighting of materials for the foundation of the second unit of the building. In June, he was informed that no further funds were available for that year and that, before anything
could be done in 1931 or later, additional authority from His Excellency in Council and a Vote by Parliament would have to be secured. At His Lordship's suggestion, I had our Architect change the plans and specifications of the administration, dormitory and classroom part of the building to fireproof construction, and I told His Lordship that I hoped the work might be proceeded with in 1931.

During 1930, the Church authorities went ahead with the making of brick, and, in February of this year, His Lordship came to Ottawa to plead for further help. In the first draft of our Main Estimates for 1931-32, I had included an item of $75,000. This had been struck out and His Lordship so informed. He, however, pressed for consideration when the supplementaries were being prepared. He was informed that no expenditure could be authorized at that time, but, as the freighting had to be done before the spring breakup, he asked the Department to reaffirm its decision to have the work done on a day labour basis, under the supervision of the Church authorities. On March 6th, I wrote to him, stating that no expenditure could be authorized this year.

His Lordship, trusting that the Department would reimburse him sooner or later, went ahead with the main part of the building this year. He is hoping to admit pupils during January, next, but I believe he should postpone the reopening of the school until the summer. At the present time, the interior is not quite finished and it is not completely furnished. I am satisfied the building is a credit to all concerned. It is fireproof and modern in all respects. Further, the cost has been much less than if a contract had been awarded.

Bishop Charlebois hopes that the Department will include an item in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year to reimburse the Church for most, if not all, of the expense. From the information on file,
$75,000 is the figure we should consider. In addition, $5,000 is required in the spring to finish and furnish the building. Further, a per-capita grant for current expenses should be provided. If you decide in favour of a second grant towards the cost of the building, another Order in Council will be necessary.

Description of work done on Beauval Indian School.

The footing began May the 15th and the plan supplied by Cowin, Co., Ltd., Structural engineers, were followed closely for the footings and reinforced concrete. A copy of the plans will also follow to the department to illustrate more closely all the details.

The four center columns were enlarged from footings to roof to support two horizontal cylindrical tanks 10'x5'. Also for the same purpose, the walls between the four center columns, are made of double bricks laid flat; that is from one foot below the basement floor to roof.

The bricks walls are 17" in thickness for basement, ground and first floor, that is three layers of bricks and air space and one brick laid on the side. The walls of the second floor have only 14" but provided also with an air space. The roof is supported by reinforced concrete columns, girders and beams, but slabs are made of 2x6" spaced between 20 to 24" resting on concrete beams. Two layers of Sylotex were laid on the 2x6" on a shiplaps and one below forming a good air space. Strips 1x2" laid on the sylotex with a shiplaps and 2" of dry sand forms the second air space.

The flat roof, groove and tongue lumber, is supported by 2x6" resting on posts, thus forming thick air space. A layer of white paper and four layers of tar paper and gravel forms the roof. The roof is provided with two four inches house drain which discharge into 3" house sewer. The drainage system consists of three main soil stocks, with all vent stocks, cleanout and traps required in modern construction. A sub soil drain is also provided all around the foundation wall.

Cool and warm water.

Cold water will be supplied by a ram forcing the water into the two
2.

Cylindrical tanks and the house supplied by gravity for cool and warm water.

Electricity:

All wires are passing through galvanized electrical pipes and the system is all fireproof.

Heating system:

The heating system amounts about 4200' of radiation. The two boilers supplied by the Vulcan Iron Winnipeg have a capacity of 3000" of radiation each. It is a two pipe system; the returns from the radiators are returned to boilers by gravity. Steam and return mains are divided respectively in four branches fitted with four valves. This system has already proved very satisfactorily.

Partitions:

All partitions are made of one layer of bricks laid flat.

Floors:

Basement floor (being short of cement) is made of one shiplap laid diagonally and birch for the finishing. Ground and first floor are rough concrete finishing. Second floor is rough concrete with strips laid on and finished as basement.

Playrooms:

Playrooms for boys and girls are well ventilated and lighted. Each room 43x34' has 6 windows. Classrooms are also provided with four windows and will be of the finest appearance when finished. Sewing room the finest for size and light is 43x34 with 11 windows. Boys and girls dormitories are of good size and well ventilated and provided with shower baths, closets and sinks and cloth stores.

All stairs are reinforced concrete.

Exterior walls were plastered with lime and whitewash. All partitions and ceilings are also whitewashed on the bricks only. Half the plumbing only could be made just now, fixtures not on hand but will be finished for January.

Sweating:

There was no sweating on exterior walls in basement and ground floors, very little in a couple rooms of first floor and on both side only. Owing to heating system working...
only on south side first. All those rooms are completely dry now.

It is very regrettable that the school could not be entirely finished at once on account of being short of different materials, although not nicely finished, the school would be ready any time to take up a certain number of children. The building is very healthful, well heated and ventilated and also finished with all the conveniences required for such a building.

At the present time, as it was hard for the Indians to strive for their life, they are sending petitions or petitions to put their children to the school, but are refused. So I hope that the Department of Indian Affairs will take up the matter into consideration and will accept those children who are well disposed to go to school.

I am:

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I.
Principal.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to refer to an Order of His Excellency in Council, P.C., 958, dated May 30, 1929. The Order aforesaid approved of a grant of $50,000.00 to the Oblate Order for the erection of a new school building for the Beauval Indian Residential School, near Lac la Plonge, in the Province of Saskatchewan, to replace that which was destroyed by fire in September, 1927. The total cost of the building was estimated at $100,000.00, and the additional $50,000.00 required was to be provided by the said Oblate Order.

The grant of $50,000.00 aforesaid was provided by Parliament and paid during the fiscal years ended March 31, 1930, and March 31, 1931. The building is now practically completed and the total cost has been approximately $125,000.00; $25,000.00 in excess of the estimate. The land on which the school is situated is owned by the department.

The Order has made representations to the department to show that their finances are unable to bear the costs incurred in connection with the erection of this Indian School, and has satisfied the department that such is the case.

In view of these circumstances and having regard to the interests of Indian education in the district served by this institution, the undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for an additional grant to the said Oblate Order of the sum of $10,000.00 towards the cost of the erection of the Beauval Indian Residential School building as aforesaid.

Funds for this purpose are available from Parliamentary Appropriation for the current fiscal year, 1932/33.

Dear Sir:

As requested by your letter of the 28th ultimo (No. I32-I-5), I am pleased to forward to you the supporting vouchers for $7,378.04 expenditure re Beauval Indian Residential School from October 31st 1931 to May 31st 1932.

Yours truly,

Secretary.
Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter May the 4th 1932 saying "not to incur any expenditure which the Department will be called upon to meet until you have full directions," I come to ask you if the department will authorize me to have some of the work done, which I think is necessary.

Last fall as we were in a hurry to close the school before the cold season, we did not have time to scrape off the earth around the building which caused the rain to remain around the foundation, and which might cause the concrete to crack. This will take a couple weeks with two scrapers. It will cost from $40 to $60.00.

I believe the Department would have no objection for me to keep a man to get the school ready for the opening as we have no benches nor tables; and also as all the other furnitures, such as doors windows have to be fixed.

I do not find any means of getting the school ready without the help of a man besides the brother.

You would obliged me very much in telling me when to send the invoices to the department. Some of the supply will be here this week; as soon as I will have the invoice, I will O.K. them and send them to the Department.

Thank you very much for what you are doing for this school.

Yours very truly,

Evêché, Le Pas, Man., le 16 septembre, 1932.

À Monsieur le Sous-Surintendant,
Des Affaires Indiennes, Ottawa, Ont.

Cher Monsieur,

Vous êtes au courant, je suppose, que les frais de la nouvelle construction de l'Ecole Pensionnat de Beauval ont été payés par nous. D'après vos dossiers, vous verrez que ces frais s'élèvent dans les environs de $140,000.00. Un remboursement de $50,000.00 a été complété par le Département Indiens le 5 juin 1930. Un autre remboursement de $10,000.00 a été fait le 28 juin 1932. Le tout forme un montant de $60,000.00 Nous subissons encore les obligations de la somme qui reste due. Les intérêts sont très onéreux pour nous. De plus nous sommes dans un grand besoin d'argent. Le développement de nos missions indiennes en souffrent beaucoup. Nous sollicitons donc avec vives instances qu'un autre remboursement substantiel, sinon complet, nous soit voté à la prochaine session.

Ainsi, je vous prie d'inscrire dans vos prochaines estimations une somme d'au moins 25 à 30 mille piastres. Sans cela nous ne pourrons pas faire face aux besoins de nos missions.

J'espère donc que vous aurez égard à notre situation et que vous vous rendrez à nos désirs.

Je vous prie d'agréer l'hommage de mon respect et de mon dévouement.

+O. Charlebois, O.M.I.

Vic. Apost. du Keewatin.

Bishop's Palace, St. Pas, May, Sept. 16, 1932

To the Acting Deputy
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

You evidently know that the cost of the new construction at the Beauval Boarding School was paid here. On your file you will see that the expenditure reaches nearly $140,000. A refund of $50,000 was completed by the Indian Department on June the 5th, 1932. Another payment of $10,000 was made on the 28th of June, 1932. Making an aggregate sum of $60,000. We are still bearing the obligations of the sum remaining due. The interests are burdensome factors. Furthermore, we are in great need of money. The development of our Indian missions suffer thereby considerably. We consequently solicit earnestly that another substantial refund be made, if not complete, by a vote at the next session.

Consequently, I beg you to include in your next estimates a sum of at least 25 to 30 thousands dollars. Without that we will be unable to meet the needs of our missions. I therefore hope that you will take our situation into consideration and will accede to our wishes.

I beg you to accept the homage of my respect and of my devotion.

(Signed) + P. Charlebois, O.M.I.

OTTAWA, Ont., September 20th 1932

The Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I received recently a letter from Rev. Father Gagnon, O.M.I., Principal of the Beauval Residential School, in which he asks if the Department would consider the suggestion of providing the school with a motor boat for the transportation of the Indian children from their distant homes. The Rev. Father shows the advisability of the suggestion in the following lines:

"Avec l'ouverture de l'école se pose un sérieux problème pour nous; celui des dépenses de voyage pour amener les enfants à l'école, et pour les reconduire dans leurs familles pour le temps des vacances.

"Nos sauvages étant tous très pauvres, ne peuvent entreprendre le voyage nécessaire pour venir mener eux-mêmes leurs enfants; ils manqueraient de vivres en route, et de plus, pour la plupart, n'ayant que de misérables canots d'écorce, ou pas de canot du tout, ils n'oseraient pas s'aventurer à faire pareil voyage même s'ils avaient des vivres en abondance. C'est parce que ces voyages sont très longs et doivent se faire en majeure partie sur des lacs qui sont de véritables mers intérieures; par exemple, le Buffalo Lake et le Clear Lake.

"C'est donc à ceux qui ont la direction de l'école que revient la tâche d'aller chercher ces enfants et à la fin de l'année de les reconduire.

"Pour vous faire une idée de la longueur de ces voyages et des dépenses qu'ils occasionnent, allons quelques chiffres: la réserve la plus rapprochée est celle du Canoe Lake, qui se trouve à 35 milles d'ici par le chemin d'hiver, mais à l'été, c'est-à-dire au temps où il faut aller prendre ou reconduire les enfants, il n'y a pas d'autre chemin praticable que celui des rivières en passant par le lac de l'Ile-a-la-Crosse, soit une distance de 70 milles pour s'y rendre. Pour les autres réserves, c'est encore plus loin. Il y a 90 milles pour se rendre à...
la réserve "English River", 110 milles pour celle du "Clear Lake", 120 milles pour Buffalo River, 200 pour le Portage-la-Loche, et 115 milles pour Water-Men River.

"Dans un même voyage on peut à la rigueur prendre les enfants de Clear Lake, Buffalo River et du Portage, mais ce seul voyage donne un parcours de 300 milles environ aller et retour. Quant aux autres réserves, pour s'y rendre il faut faire un voyage spécial pour chacune. Et puis, comme je le disais tout à l'heure, à cause des grands lacs à traverser, il n'y a presque pas moyen de s'arrêter à l'idée de faire ces voyages avec les canots dont nous nous servons pour les besoins ordinaires. Je tremble à la seule pensée de me faire prendre par un gros temps sur un lac avec une charge d'enfants dans une embarcation quelconque. S'il fallait qu'il arrivât quelque malheur dans le transport, quelle responsabilité pour moi! Et pour ce qui est de l'école, il va sans dire qu'il serait inutile ensuite d'essayer d'avoir des enfants.

"De ce qui précède, je crois pouvoir conclure que le transport des enfants aux frais de l'école s'impose, et que pour cela il faudrait avoir un petit bateau qui assurerait une certaine sécurité en cas de mauvais temps pendant les voyages.

"Assurément cela représente encore un joli déboursé pour le Département, mais je suppose que ceux qui s'occupent des affaires indiennes voudront bien admettre qu'il y a là un état de choses auquel nous ne pouvons rien changer........

"Pour toutes ces raisons, j'ose espérer que le Département nous accordera, pour la prochaine année scolaire, un petit bateau pour transporter les élèves, et en plus, un octroi suffisant pour couvrir les dépenses de voyage.".....

Yours very truly,

F. X. Maricotte, D.M.I.
Ottawa, Ont., September 20, 1932.

The Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I received recently a letter from Rev. Father Gagnon, O.M.I., Principal of the Beauval Residential School, in which he asks if the Department would consider the suggestion of providing the school with a motor boat for the transportation of the Indian children from their distant homes. The Rev. Father shows the advisability of the suggestion in the following lines:

"After the opening of the school a serious problem arises for us, that of the travelling expenses to bring the children to school and to take them back to their families for the time of their holidays.

"Our Indians being very poor, cannot undertake the necessary voyage to bring their children themselves; the lack of food to undertake that trip and furthermore most of them having only poor bark canoes or none at all, they would not dare to venture on a trip of that kind even if they had abundant food supply. It is because these trips are very long and are done mostly over lakes which are real interior seas; such as, for example, Buffalo Lake and Clear Lake.

"It is consequently, to those who have the direction of the school that the task of fetching these children, falls on, and also that of returning them home at the end of the year.

"To give you an idea of the length of these trips and the expense incurred, we will show some figures: The nearest reserve is that of Canoe Lake which is at 35 miles from here in Winter, but in summer, that is to say, at the time when we have to bring and return the children, there is no other practical way than that of the rivers by passing through Lake Ile a la Crosse, that is a distance of 70 miles to reach it. For the other reserves it is still farther. There is a

---distance---
distance of 90 miles to reach the reserve of English River, 110 miles to reach that of Clear Lake, 120 miles for Buffalo River, 200 for the Portage la Loche, and 115 miles for Water-Hen River.

"In the same trip we could, by special arrangement, take the children of Clear Lake, Buffalo River, and Portage, but this sole trip constitutes a round trip of about 300 miles. As to the other reserves we would have to make a special trip to reach each one of them. Furthermore, as I said here above, on account of the great lakes to cross there is almost no possibility of thinking of making these trips with the canoes that we use for ordinary service. I tremble at the mere thought of being caught by a storm on the lake with a load of children in any kind of boat. If there was any accident in the transportation, what a responsibility that would be for me! Concerning the school, it goes without saying, that it would be then useless to try to have any more pupils.

"Of what precedes I believe that I can conclude that the transportation of the children at the expense of the school is imperative and for that purpose we would need a small boat which would insure security in case of bad weather during these trips.

"Of course, this represents again certain disbursement for the Department, but I suppose that those who are in charge of Indian Affairs will kindly admit that there is, in this case, a state of affairs which we cannot possibly change.

"For all these reasons I dare hope that the Department will grant us for the next scholar year, a small boat for the transportation of the pupils, and furthermore a grant sufficient to cover the travelling expenses.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) F. X. Marcotte, O.M.I.
Ottawa, October 1st, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo, regarding the request of Reverend Father Gagnon, O.M.I., Principal of the Beauval Indian Residential School, to provide the school with a motor boat to be used for the transportation of Indian children to and from their homes. In reply I have to say that this will be noted for consideration when our Estimates are being prepared for the coming fiscal year but the Department can give no assurance that the amount required for the purpose can be provided.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. F. X. Marcotte, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Ottawa, Ont.
