Dear Mr. Murison:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools which I inspected during the time I was Paying Officer for the Ile a la Crosse Agency.

Beauval School

I visited this school on June 11th and remained at Beauval till noon of the 12th.

The Staff of this institution are as follows:
Reverend Father F. X. Gagnon, Principal; Brother Beaudoin, Carpenter and Engineer; Brother August Duclos; Sister Superior Chevrifils; Sister Eidelin, teacher grades 1 to IV, inclusive; Sister Carrier, Matron; Sister Robinson, Nurse; Sister Hurtubise in charge of kitchen; Sister Roy, in charge of sewing and laundry.

The Reverend Father Gagnon impressed me as being an outstanding man, conscientious, keen, and apparently very capable in supervising this institution. He informs me he has a fine staff of employees here. I found them apparently working in harmony and giving co-operative and conscientious service.

Owing to the fact that the new school was not finished inside there were only 19 girl pupils present at the time of my visit. These were given examination in the various subject, pertaining to Grades 1 to IV. I found they appeared to have a good grasp of and were well advanced in their respective grades, spoke up well and seemed keenly interested in their work. These pupils were nicely dressed, appeared to be a well nourished clean, healthy, and happy lot of children. These - children -

W. Murison, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.
children are also instructed in sewing, knitting, fancy work, cooking, laundry work, milking cows, and attending poultry.

The Reverend Principal informed me this school would be opened about the 1st September and expected a total attendance of one hundred pupils. The boys receive a training (in addition to their studies) in the following, carpentry, blacksmithing, electric and steam engineering, saw mill work, and grain and stock raising.

Buildings

As you are aware the material and work performed on this building was supplied by the Oblate Fathers. In my opinion this building has been well constructed and in a manner to make it 100% fire proof. The basement is divided into the following;—boys' recreation room, girls' recreation room, Sisters' room, Fathers' room, Senior boys' room, Junior boys' room, kitchen, pantry, laundry, dairy, main dining room, machine room, boiler room, fire room, boys' toilet and girls' toilet. These rooms are all floored with birch. On the first floor there is reception room, private parlor, three rooms for visitors, three classrooms, workshop and dispensary. One classroom is floored with birch and the balance of the floors are rough cement finish. The second floor is divided into sewing room, girls' infirmary, boys' infirmary, with a separate room joining each of the infirmaries for the Sister in charge; Sisters' community room, five rooms for Staff, one store room for school supplies, one Sisters' bathroom, toilet and baths for girls, toilet and baths for boys. There are two rooms on this floor with birch flooring. The third floor is divided into boys' dormitory, capacity fifty beds; girls' dormitory, capacity fifty beds, with sleeping room adjoining each of these for attendants. All floors in this storey are birch. These dormitories are equipped with shower baths and toilets. In the attic there are two water tanks with a capacity of 2,000 gallons each. This building, although not finished...
not finished inside, is fit for use. The Reverend Father Gagnon estimates that it would require the employment of ten men for a term of two months to finish same. The walls of the rooms are rough brick and whitewashed inside and covered with a mixture of lime and sand outside. Other than the rough cement, there is no flooring in any of the hallways, as there was not sufficient cement to make a smooth finish. The Reverend Principal informs me that there is still floor space of 74,240 square feet to be finished. Of this area 6,570 feet is in hallways. He requested that this institution be assisted by the Department in procuring sufficient flooring for the hallways. Adjoining this building is the Church Chapel, 30 x 60 feet. However there is no danger of fire ever reaching the school from the Chapel. All other outbuildings are placed some distance from the school. These are as follows; Father's residence, warehouse, cattle barn, horse barn, pig barn, chicken house, route house, saw mill, machine shed, and ice house. I noticed this institution has no fire fighting apparatus in the school building, but I am quite satisfied that the building is absolutely fire proof. The only wood used in the construction of it is in the beams and joists, which are timber but well covered with cement. In the event of the floors that are covered with birch catching fire, this would not in any way endanger the safety of the building, as the walls are all solid brick and finished as heretofore mentioned.

This school has the following live stock; 1 Shorthorn bull, 15 milk cows, 33 beef cows and steers, 12 calves, 18 horses, 5 colts, 2 brood sows, 9 pigs, and 1 Yorkshire boar. In addition they have 125 head of poultry. All this stock appear to be of a good type. The Principal informs me that they have difficulty in procuring hay for their cattle and horses. Apparently high water effects these meadows to the same extent - as it does -
as it does others throughout this North country, and the Principal was seriously thinking of dispensing with the milk cows and introducing goats to take their place. While here I visited all the crop fields and found them well cultivated and the crops well advanced. These fields were seeded to oats, wheat, barley, potatoes, and tubers. Last year they yielded 1800 bus. of oats, 300 bus. of wheat, 450 bus. of barley, 700 bus. of potatoes, and 800 bus. of tubers from an area of 65 acres. This year they have in crop the following areas; 6 acres of grass for pasture purposes, 40 acres of oats, 6 acres of wheat, 10 acres of barley, 3 acres of tubers, and have cleaned a further four acres for future use.

In going over the buildings and grounds at this institution I found that all buildings were in a good state of repair, clean and tidy within. The grounds were well kept and were being further improved by the planting of flowers and shrubbery.

I found the Principal of this school very appreciative of the help this institution has already received from the Department. He was very modest in asking for further help and requested that, if the Department were allowing money grants to the Residential Schools in Canada this year, he be given further assistance in procuring some covering for the hall-ways of the new school. Owing to these hallways not being hard finish, they are beginning to show wear and the Father informs me that the footwear of the staff and pupils lasts but a very short time on this account. I found that through the efforts and sacrifices of the members of this institution, they have accomplished something that this whole North country is proud of, in that they are the only institution North of Township 54 that can give the children of this country an education and training equal to that of institutions only found in the larger settlements of the west. In view of this, I would recommend that further assistance be -
Assistance be given them if possible.

Lac la Ronge Church of England Residential School...

I arrived at this school on the night of July 6th, remaining here until leaving for Stanley on July 12th.

Owing to the school being closed for the summer vacation and rainy weather, the Reverend Mr. Fisher, Principal, allowed me the use of one of the classrooms for the purpose of making annuity payments and holding Band meetings.

I found the Reverend Mr. Fisher conscientious and keen in his service to this institution. This was reflected in the general atmosphere of keen co-operation apparent between this man and his staff, which are as follows: Miss E.V. Williams Matron, F.E. Simonson, 1st teacher, Mr. Crozier, 2nd teacher, C. Poney, Girls' Supervisor, B. Baird, Boys' Supervisor, E. Smith, Kitchen Matron, D. Mathews, Laundress, N.L. Patrick, Nurse, A.C. Hastings, Engineer, T.A. Mills, Farmer, and C.C. Brown, Fisherman.

Owing to the school being closed as already mentioned, I did not examine the class work of the pupils. However, during the payment here and at Stanley I came in contact with many of them. In addressing these I found them well mannered, clean, tidy, neatly dressed, and apparently well nourished, and I found they would join in conversation more readily than many Indian pupils I have met. They expressed a keen interest in their school work and seemed very loyal to the institution.

I found the school and other buildings pertaining thereto clean and tidy within and the grounds without very nicely kept.
The Reverend Principal informed me there were about 2000' of lumber left over after using that authorized by the Department. This surplus is being used to good advantage, mainly in building partitions in the upper dormitory for the girls, which will accommodate ten small beds and a staff room. Partitions are also being built to separate the smaller boys from the larger, and any surplus lumber will be used for general repairs to buildings. The floors and ceilings of the upper balcony were not completed. I was advised they will be this fall. The Principal requested that wire screening 5' x 65' be provided for this. It could then be used for isolation cases during the summer months.

I found the chimney of this building has been repaired, but does not draw well at times, resulting in soot overflowing and running down it; and on these occasions the building becomes smoky and the inside walls thereof are stained. I also noticed the basement joists have been protected with asbestos from the heat of the furnace pipes, also a new fire box installed in one of the furnaces. In checking over the fire Protection equipment I find further protection can be given by supplying a 50' x 5/8" garden hose and placing it in the upper dormitory to be used in case of chimney fires, also that recharges are necessary for the following fire extinguishers, 24 recharges Guardene Fire Ext. No. A 606201 capacity 2½ gals., 12 recharges for Pyrene No. P 204607 1 quart type.

The interior of the school building should be redecorated in that many of the walls are stained, and paint worn off some of the floors and part of the wood-work. I also noticed moss growing between the crevices of the shingles on the roof which should be stained or repainted. My attention was also drawn to the fact that some of the dormitory beds need replacing badly, whereas a little enamel paint would improve the appearance of others.
The farm stock consists of 4 milk cows, a team of horses, and 36 hens. These are not adequate to supply the general demand made on them. I find the nature of the land here is not adaptable for cultivation and the Principal informs me that it is only with some effort on the part of this institution that enables them to maintain what little stock they have. In this I concur.

In going over the land I was forcibly impressed with the fact that this institution will never support its staff and members by any produce derived therefrom, regardless of the amount of labour expended in any attempt to do so. While here, I was questioned concerning a further grant of land to them.

Apart from the requirements already mentioned, I find this school require the following:

- New Rear Start for Fairbanks Morse 32 volt Lighting plant.
- 2 toilet bowls with flush tanks (as replacements)
- 1 wash basin with fittings as there is only 1 toilet room for students in this building.
- 2 Doz. beds and mattress 6 x 2½ for replacements
- 1000 shingles for repairing roof.
- 50 gal. roof paint - green or creosot.
- 1 gal. white enamel paint for bedsteads.
- 15 gal. floor paint - grey for dormitory floors.
- 3 gals. turpentine.
- 6 lbs. dry burnt water.
- 7 gals. floor varnish for halls and dining room.
- 3 furnace door linings for McClary Famous Magnet furnace No. H10 A.

In view of the effort involved by this institution in an endeavour to carry on the good and only work of its kind in this section of the North, I would respectfully request they be given special consideration in grants the Department may be considering for these institutions.
Stanley Day School

I visited this school on July 15th, and found 29 pupils present with Mr. T.W. Gilmore as teacher. The pupils appeared clean, healthy and well clothed.

In taking the classes in their various subjects I noticed some of the pupils were much further advanced than the majority, in spite of there being little or no difference in their ages. In questioning Mr. Filmore regarding this he informed me the backward pupils were those who attended school during the summer months only. He also advised me that owing to the fact that these children attended school for three or four months, and then lived with their people during the balance of the year, resulted in them forgetting what they had learned at school.

In view of this it would appear to be a wasted effort in trying to teach these children under those conditions. However I found the children who had attended their classes during the winter months well advanced in their studies. These appeared keen and interested in their work, and all seemed anxious to return to their school this winter.

The Chief and members of this band are very anxious to keep this school open during the yearly school term, and have voted the sum of $600.00 to be taken from band funds for that purpose. Dispensation of same as follows:

$50.00 a year for housing, cooking & washing for girl pupils.
$50.00 a year for " " " " for boy pupils.
$50.00 a year for labor to supply fuel and fish to the above.
$200.00 a year for food supplies from Revillon Freres Trading Co., Stanley.
$250.00 to ship in the following: 5 sacks flour, 100 lbs. pot barley, 100 lbs. rolled oats, 50 lbs. sugar, 25 lbs. tea, 36 lbs. lard and 200 candles.

These people advised me that if they could be assured this school was to be kept open the year round they would guarantee to increase the yearly average daily attendance.
daily attendance from 24:01 to 45. In so doing the provider of each family would be able to give more time to his hunting and trap lines during the winter months.

I am attaching hereto the resolution, signed by the Chief and Head Men, which was witnessed by me, and would recommend it be given favorable consideration.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

S.H. Simpson.
Paying Officer.
Sir:

I beg to forward a report on the schools included in the Ile a la Crosse Agency submitted by the Paying Officer for this year, Mr. S. H. Simpson.

Beauval School

It is interesting to note that the new residential school building at Beauval has been well constructed and is apparently a fire proof building. It will be noted that there is still some finishing to do and the Principal has requested assistance in connection with flooring for the hallways. There is no flooring in any of the hallways, except rough cement. The report deals quite fully with conditions at the school and speaks for itself.

Lac la Ronge Res. School

This report gives a general idea of conditions and sets out in detail the requirements as presented to him. You will note on Page 7 he mentions that he was questioned regarding a further grant of land to them. I took this matter up quite fully last year, looked over the ground, and made a recommendation regarding land which might be set aside. This is a matter which I think should receive some attention before it is too late to secure suitable land. There is very little fit for cultivation in that whole area and it is important, if this school is to be continued, that sufficient arable land be secured upon.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
secured upon which to grow the feed requirements of the stock belonging to the institution.

Stanley Day School

The report in connection with this Day School is not encouraging in view of the living conditions of the people. As these people derive their living by hunting and trapping, it is absolutely impossible for them to reside continuously at Stanley. Their means of livelihood takes them considerable distance from that point and it is obvious that, unless residential facilities are provided for the school children to enable them to remain at Stanley all the year round, we cannot expect a regular and satisfactory attendance. It will be noted on Page 8 of the report the Paying Officer states that the Chief and members of this Band are anxious to keep the school open during the term and have voted the sum of $600.00 to be taken from their Band funds for that purpose. I question the advisability of doing this. The funds of the Band are very limited and after all the granting of this money would only be a temporary expedient, as, if the funds are to be used from year to year for this purpose, they would soon become depleted and we would be confronted with the same situation as exists at present. In view of the resolutions having been passed, I am submitting them herewith.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

W. Morrison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Memorandum:

DR. MCGILL.

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School.

In connection with the preparation of Estimates for 1933-34, regarding a grant to reimburse the church authorities for the expenditure incurred in the erection of the new building at the Beauval Indian Residential School, in northern Saskatchewan - for which a grant is included in our Estimates - I beg to report as follows:

In September, 1927, the old building was destroyed by fire, and Bishop Charlebois, representing the Oblate Order, offered to rebuild if the Department would give a grant of $50,000. The Department accepted this proposal, which was approved by P. C. 932, of May 30, 1929. The new building was to be erected by the Order, on a day labour basis. The land on which the school is situated is owned by the Department. During the year commencing June, 1929, this grant of $50,000 was paid. Approximately $63,000 was expended by the church authorities during that year.

In October, 1929, His Lordship intimated that there was a misunderstanding regarding financing and that the Oblate Order would require considerably more than the $50,000 if the building programme was to be completed. Early in 1930, His Lordship, hoping that the Department would be able to make an additional grant, arranged for the freighting of materials for the foundation of the second unit of the building. In February, 1931, His Lordship came to Ottawa to plead for further help. No financial assistance was given him by the Department at that time. On his own responsibility, however, he began construction of the main part of the building, and an additional grant of $10,000 was paid the church authorities by P. C. 1326, of the 13th June, 1932.

His Lordship, in a communication dated September 16th, last, states that the total expenditure in the erection of the building was approximately $140,000, towards which the Department provided the sum of $60,000, as stated above. He strongly urged that a further substantial refund be made in our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

I have outlined this matter, in order that you may have the facts before you. The Minister and the Department were quite clear regarding the understanding which resulted in the Order in Council of the 30th of May, 1929. Bishop Charlebois gave nothing in writing but he held interviews with both the Minister and the late Mr. Ferrier.

While in one sense the Department is not responsible for the present situation, it should be remembered that the Beauval School in the past was considered a useful institution and that it constitutes at present a valuable adjunct to our educational system. I would therefore support the provision of funds to further reimburse His Lordship to an amount of at least $10,000.

Sir:

BEAUVAL RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL Sept. 27th.

The harvesting at the school was all completed and produce stored for winter and with a few exceptions was sufficient till next year. Plowing and spading was in progress all over and a new septic tank on up-to-date plans, with complete drainage and ditching was under construction, generally it was a busy place.

The Water Power which operates everything at the school, had been doubtful during low water seasons, so this year a Dam was constructed at the mouth of the river near Lake La Plonge and a second one at the Power Plant, this was all done at a heavy expense to the school and it was well done on regular engineering plans and will assure a steady supply of water. A further report on this and the septic tank will be sent to the Department as soon as full particulars are available.

The new buildings as usual are in perfect condition and the whole premises are clean and orderly, some of the old buildings are being renovated, and the Rev. Principal has regular Plans of the whole layout made to scale, some of the old buildings out of place on the plan are being moved to allow for roadways and in future every addition or move will be according to plan and as they can and do produce all their own building materials including shingles and excepting cement, every new building will be a credit to the school.

The Live Stock are all in fine condition and of good quality, many of the cows are Holstein strain and bred to Shirthorn and they have fine Registered Bull purchased recently. The work horses are all heavy averaging about 1600 and well conditioned, even after a heavy season of work, and a trip through the barns, pastures and fields, leaves you convinced of good farming ability, good management and supervision and shows that the Rev. Principal als past and present have been on the job.

Dear Mr. Macdonald,

I did not wish to trouble you with my requests during your recent visit to Beauval. But what a number of things I could have presented to you, that I could have discussed with you!

During the past year, the Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin has had to bear very heavy expenses for the maintenance of the School: 1-Construction of two dams, to insure at all times sufficient water power for electrical purposes and for domestic purposes. In previous years, when low water occurred, there was no water at all for a period of about three months. 2-Reconstruction of Septic Tank. 3-Making of articles of furniture indispensable to the school. Taking these items only, we get the following figures:

LaPlonge Lake Dam --- $1500.00
LaPlonge River Dam and dredging river 2200.00
Septic Tank --------- 900.00
Furniture --------- 225.00

4825.00

All these projects were done at our own expense, since even though you approved of them you could not promise immediate support, and we, on the other hand, had a pressing need of these improvements.

I allow myself to make a brief exposition of these things to remind you, what otherwise you have already credited us with, that we certainly do our part for the maintenance and good functioning of our school.

But in spite of what has been done in the past, there is still a great deal to be done. And some items are of an urgent nature. Expecting that through your personal influence the ministers of the Department will readily come to our assistance, I briefly expose our most pressing needs.
From now on we are assured of a permanent water supply. We would like to solve a dual problem, source of heavy expenses and difficulties, that can only be well understood by one who has been through them day after day.

The two main items are: Our pumping system, our electrical system. Both of them are far from being powerful enough, even when functioning at their best, which happens very seldom, and only a few days in succession. This comes from the fact that ever since the opening of the school, five years ago, we have tried to get along and keep things going, by using various means of fortune and fixing things temporarily. But this cannot last any longer, and at least for the winter of 1937-38 it is absolutely necessary for us to be provided with new equipment to furnish us with light and water.

We have always also been without a workshop for blacksmith and shoe repairs. So we have thought of asking for authorization to build a shop where we would have all machinery necessary for electric light, pump, blacksmith, carpentering and shoe repairing. All this would be operated by a hydraulic turbine.

Now, let me clearly explain what we expect from the Government. Knowing the scant resources that the Indian Department can affect to such improvements in schools, I have endeavored to come to conditions, which I confidently hope, will prove acceptable.

First, I would ask that in all this, the material only would be granted us. After consultation with Bishop Lajeunesse, for costs incurred in transportation from terminal as well as for construction of workshop and installation of machinery, I would gladly take the responsibility. This is to show you that we wish to collaborate with the Department and also to obtain if possible, that we receive help in bringing an immediate solution to these problems.

In short, here is what my request amounts to:

About 1000 bags Cement
A few thousand lbs. Sheathing Iron
Tin covering
One Hydraulic Turbine
One Pump
One Dynamo
A big metal Pipe to carry water to Turbine about 250 ft. long.
We have already sent in our request for sufficient

1200 ft. of 2" steel pipes and fittings required for pump.

So the above would be the Government's contribution to this project, while ours would consist of transportation charges, construction of shop, installation of machinery, all lumber needed, besides bricks, lime, sand and stone.

Under separate cover, you will find detailed information concerning machinery, proposed construction, and site of same.

By what precedes, it is quite clear that our request is very reasonable, besides being absolutely urgent. So we earnestly hope, that with your sanction, this project will receive the approval of the ministers of the Department.

I beg to remain, as always,

Yours gratefully,

Mr. S. L. Macdonald,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

The Beauval Indian Residential School, conducted under the auspices of the Oblate Order, was totally destroyed by fire September 19th, 1927. The Church authorities erected a new building, to accommodate one hundred pupils, during the years 1929 and 1930. The total cost incurred in the erection of the building was $134,763.86. I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of March 12th, enclosing letter received from Right Reverend Martin Lajeunesse, C.M.I., Vicar-Apostolic of Kewatin, with reference to a balance of $1,000.00 in connection with the construction of the Beauval Indian Residential School.

Our records indicate that the above mentioned amount is actually due His Lordship and I enclose necessary Order-in-Council. I should appreciate if you could facilitate its passing in order that the amount may be paid from our appropriation for the current fiscal year.

Bishop Lajeunesse's letter is returned herewith.

Gentlemen:

With reference to your letter of November 25th last, I have been gathering information about our needs. The 20 H.P. Turbine is about what we want. We need as well a dynamo developing twelve kilowatts; and a water pump, for which the specifications would be: two-inch pipe, distance from intake to tank about 800 feet or run with 120 feet of head level. The tanks hold about 5000 gallons, which is approximately the average daily amount used.

Drawings are enclosed showing the place where turbine is to be installed. There are two places where the channel may be built from the dam to the turbine: one leading off above the dam, and running underground to the turbine, and the other much shorter and running on top of the ground directly from the dam. There would be a difference in level of about 1½ feet from one end of the pipe to the other. The drop of the turbine well will be at least 15 feet and could easily be arranged to obtain as much as a 16-foot drop.

It is most important that we have the main shaft of the turbine going all the way through the working shop, with pulleys or drive belts for the dynamo, water pump, and for other machinery.

I would like you to send me, with the smallest possible delay, your definite price for this equipment: the turbine, dynamo, water pump, and the proper steel pipe, with leads and fittings, for the channel to the turbine.

I think it would be advisable for us to have one of your engineers to supervise the installation, in case we should agree with your prices; the installation would be made in June or July of 1938, the machinery being freighted in to this point during the coming winter. It is necessary to submit your answer to the Department of Indian Affairs, and I am very anxious to hear from you as soon as possible. Any advice you can give will be much appreciated.

Kindly return the enclosed drawings when you are finished with them.

Yours very truly,

V. Bleau O.M.I.,

BIG REASONS WHY
Patented Removable Liners
SAVE MONEY for WESTCO USERS

1. Lifetime service from Pump Casings.
2. Less metal required for alloy construction.
3. "Stand-by" pump protection available at about ¼ usual cost.
4. Capacity of pump can be increased and decreased.

PUMP users throughout industry have been quick in voicing their approval of Westco's new patented Removable Liner feature. It is a welcome improvement on a pump that has made a name for itself by proving its superiority on thousands of different applications both in this country and abroad.

Just as the name suggests, Removable Liners are simply a lining for the Westco pump casings proper. They form the liquid channel and are quickly and easily removed from the pump casings. To every pump user, we believe the valuable advantages of this feature will be of great interest.

Lifetime Service from Casings

Seldom, if ever, need the Westco Pump casings be replaced. This is a statement of fact because, in this modern pump, all interior surfaces which are subject to wear and deterioration are incorporated in the Liners.

As explained in the following paragraphs, the cost of these Liners is so much less than the cost of the complete casings that real savings can be effected if reconditioning is ever necessary in the years to come.
This job can be done without disturbing the installation of the pump or piping connections. No need for returning pump to the factory. By following simple instructions, it is possible, in a few minutes' time, to interchange new Liners for the old.

Cuts Cost of Alloy Construction

Liners and Impeller which direct and pump the liquid can be economically made of alloy metals for it is in and around these parts that the velocity of the liquid is greatest and, consequently, corrosion most rapid.

Often, this allows cast-iron or bronze casings to be used with complete satisfaction and, of course, considerable saving of money. This is possible because the amount of comparatively high cost alloy metal required to make the Liners and Impeller is about 73% less than the amount required for casting the complete pump casings.

"Stand-By" Pump Protection

An extra set of Liners and Impeller may be carried on hand for possible use in emergencies. This practice furnishes "stand-by" pump protection at a cost about ¼ the usual price of an auxiliary pump.

ALL Westco Turbine Pumps have a double-suction Intake which creates a perfect hydraulic balance. Ingenious design of vertically split casings permits ready removal of Liners, Impeller-shaft unit and bearings (complete disassembly) without disturbing suction or discharge piping connections.

On those duties where service interruptions would prove expensive and the cost of auxiliary pumps is an important factor, this feature will be of real interest to the pump buyer.

Capacity Can Be Varied

Removable Liners in a Westco Turbine Pump enable the capacity and head to be readily increased or decreased within reasonable limits. This is accomplished by simply interchanging a different size set of Liners and Impeller.

Such flexibility of capacity further insures maximum return on your investment in Westco Turbine Pumps, because they can be shifted from duty to duty without sacrificing efficiency when different capacities and heads are required.

HOW WESTCO WORKS

The multivaned, bronze impeller is the ONLY moving part in a Westco Turbine Pump and it operates without metal-to-metal contact. Think of it — metallic friction is entirely eliminated. The result is trouble-free performance throughout an exceptionally long service life.

The liquid enters the Westco Pump at the suction intake where it finds its way to the bottom (or inlet) of the impeller vanes and by centrifugal force the direction of flow is through the vanes to the periphery of the impeller where it enters the pump channel.

Westco's multivaned Impeller reenergizes the liquid thereby producing a multistage effect. This is accomplished with only one Impeller. The result is considerably less velocity of the liquid and, consequently, less churning and erosion. When necessary, Westcos develop high pressures in single-stage construction that would require a multistage, conventional centrifugal type pump. This means less friction, simplified construction and greater economy of operation.

Figure 4 briefly illustrates the flow through the vanes while the liquid is traveling around the pump channel in the direction of rotation of the impeller.

By this explanation, you can readily see how each vane on the impeller is a pump in itself—each imparting its proportional share of energy to the liquid in its travel around through the pump channel. That is why Westco is often described as being "100 Pumps within a Pump".

Ottawa, September 14, 1937

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo enclosing plans, specifications and a quotation from the Dominion Bridge Company, Winnipeg, in connection with proposed equipment at the Beauval Indian Residential School for lighting and pumping systems.

The estimate of the Dominion Bridge Company is approximately $14,000.00. This is considerably higher than the quotation contained in your letter of November 4th, 1936, and it is apparent that if the request of the Reverend Principal is granted, the expenditure will be extremely heavy.

Before making a definite decision the Department requires considerable additional information as follows:

1. Is the Beauval Residential School wired for electricity, and have the school authorities been developing electricity from the present water power?

2. Before expending any money on the water power development did the school authorities have the advantage of expert opinion? If so, you should state who was consulted at that time.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.
3. What is the head of water in the lake as the result of the erection of the dam mentioned in the Reverend Principal's letter?

4. Have the school authorities carefully considered the fact that if the new machinery suggested by the Dominion Bridge Company were supplied it would require a great deal of water to operate it and, as a result, the quantity of water available for other purposes might not be sufficient?

5. Have the school authorities considered the advisability of generating their electric current by means of a steam plant or a Diesel engine? Information that the Department has received indicates that either system would be much cheaper than the proposed water power installation. Of course, to operate a steam plant successfully it would be necessary to have plenty of wood available for some years to come. Is this available in the vicinity of Beauval? To operate a Diesel engine plant would it be possible to obtain the necessary fuel oil at a cost that would not be prohibitive?

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Principal of the Beauval Residential School, and the Department would appreciate an early reply both from him and from yourself. You can understand that when such a large amount is involved it is felt that very complete information should be available before proceeding on any plan that might prove unworkable in the future. It may even be necessary to send a qualified electrical engineer to Beauval to survey the situation, but a decision in this regard will not be made until your reply is received.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Residential School,
Beauval, Sask.
September 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have a copy of your letter to Mr. S. L. Macdonald in connection with equipment for the school here, and am pleased to have the opportunity to answer the Department's questions.

The estimate made by Father V. Bleau, c.m.j., in a letter to Mr. Macdonald written last November, proves to be very much lower than the quotation made by Dominion Bridge Company. It was made in good faith, but without an adequate knowledge of the probable cost of the equipment required. It did not, moreover, include freight charges to Beauval, which is a part of the Dominion Bridge quotation, and must amount to perhaps $3000 of the total cost.

The school itself, and the buildings in connection with it, are all wired for electricity. The school authorities have been developing electricity from the water power of the La Plonge river at this site since 1908; and have been using the water power to run a sawmill at the same site for as long a period. The generator and turbine used now for the development of electricity are those originally installed in 1908. They no longer develop enough power for the needs of the school, and the building itself is falling down and must be replaced.

The site has not been inspected by a qualified engineer; but Mr. J. A. Burnouf of Beauval, who installed the original equipment, was consulted, and also Brother Beaudoin of the School staff, who has been working in water power since his youth in Quebec, and has had here at Beauval a continuous experience of 14 years using the water power of the La Plonge river; and also Brother Gauthier, who installed the water power development at McIntosh School. Although these men are not qualified engineers they have had a great deal of experience with water power and their opinions could be relied on.

The dam at Lake La Plonge, four miles from the School, was built to keep a surplus of water in the lake for power development at the school during dry years. The dam at the school provides a fall of 14 feet, which could easily be made 16 feet if it were necessary, according to level instrument.

The dams were built to keep a head of water for use in generating electricity, and this has been done at considerable expense. The only other purpose for which the power is used is to operate a sawmill during about ten days in the spring of the year, when seepage from the surrounding muskegs provides enough water to operate the mill and the
Generator both, at a time when the school is only using light for about one hour at night. There has been no trouble due to insufficient water. The piping to the generator in use now is 24", and we would suggest that 24" or 30" piping be used in the new equipment, between dam and turbine.

Development of power by both steam plant and Diesel engine have been considered, but these methods had numerous disadvantages. The cost of buying, freighting, and installing a boiler would be large; its operation would require the continual services of an engineer, and would be an ever-present source of danger in the hands of an inexperienced or careless man. Cordwood is available in the vicinity of the school but quantities of it are used yearly for fuel, and there is no long-time assurance of a supply of it because of the simple fact that, as during the present year, forest fires are continually laying waste thousands of acres of timber through the north and at any time may destroy our own supplies. Hauling and cutting of cordwood would also be a continual expense. It was also the opinion of the school authorities that a steam plant would not last as long as a turbine.

As for the Diesel engine, this would again entail the yearly expense of an engineer qualified to run it, and the cost of fuel oil would be prohibitive, since the school is situated 120 miles from railhead at Big River by winter freight road, or 200 miles by waterways, and freight charges would be from $1.25 to $1.75 per hundred pounds.

It is possible that the turbine may cost more than either steam or Diesel power to install, but we believe that it will be both safer and less expensive in the long run. We do not see any reason why it might prove unworkable in the future. The Episcopal Corporation of Kaswatin has spent money to build up dams to provide a sufficient head of water, and they have long been ready to cooperate with the Department on this matter. You can be assured that the matter has been thoroughly considered. It would be advisable to send a supervisor to take charge of the installation.

Yours very truly,

G. B. Saguenay, M.D.
F. A. Gagnon, C.M.I.
(Principal)

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
However as the Expenditure is so large, I certainly would not like to be responsible for any error in either Equipment or Installation and I do not think there is anyone at the school qualified, they have some good Mechanics but this is specializing and I would certainly recommend that a qualified Engineer be sent there to verify or correct any chance of errors, before any definite action is taken and this should be at an early date or before freeze up approximately Oct 20th, after which all plane traffic is tied up till Skees can be used, also while there is open water he would have a better chance to measure the flow. There is a considerable Drop from the lake to the school and all of 30 feet more at plant and into the Beaver River.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter 132-1-5, Sept 14th 1937, re Equipment for the Water Power at Beauval School. The Estimate as sent in by the Principal was as I understand based on prices he had received from some manufacturing Co and is certainly far the figures of the Dominion Bridge Co.

No.1. The School is all wired and has been operating from Water Tower for years.

No.2. No expert was called in to my knowledge and I am under the impression that the requirements were made by the School Mechanic and Principal with the help of Mr Bourneuf and Ex-brother and also Mechanical Expert who installed the present System.

No.3. No Head of Water I could not give, but La Plonge is a large lake and they have a Dam built last year at the mouth of the River about 3 Miles from the School and another at the Lower Plant, I do not however think that there is any possible fear of water shortage and they have used this for all Purposes including a Mill for over 25 years to my knowledge.

No.4. Covered in above.

No.5. An Oil burning outfit up there would be costly, as transportation costs are heavy. There is unlimited wood, however with the perfect supply of water tower which once installed, runs practically at no cost, and within 100 yards of the buildings, any other system would be out of Place.

The Church Authorities have just transferred the Rev Fr Bleau to Cross Lake, Man., and Rev F.X.Cagno, former principal has again taken over, but apparently intends to go ahead with the plans from a letter just received from him. I am leaving for Beauval and Canoe Lake on Sunday Sept 26th and will take this up further while there.
Ottawa, October 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department received your letter of September 24th, also Reverend Father Gagnon's letter of September 21st in connection with the water power plant at the Beauval Indian Residential School. The contents of both these letters were very carefully considered, but, in view of the large expenditure that is necessary, our engineers consider that it is undesirable to take any action without first sending an engineer to look over the whole situation.

From the information contained in the latter part of your letter it is now considered too late in the year to send an engineer. Arrangements will, however, be made to send an engineer early in the Spring. Please let me know the earliest date in the Spring that weather conditions will likely permit an engineer reaching the Beauval school. It should be understood that we wish this officer to be at Beauval when the lake is opened in order that he may obtain water levels and other necessary data.

Provision is being made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39 for necessary funds in order that, in the event of our engineer reporting favorably, money will be available.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

S.L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School.

In our appropriation for the current fiscal year provision was made for the following equipment for the above-mentioned school:

| Item          | Cost   |
|---------------|--------|
| Hydraulic turbine | $3000.00 |
| Pump           | $250.00 |
| Dynamo         | $500.00 |
| Metal pipe     | $250.00 |

It appears from previous correspondence that there is an electric plant at present in operation at this school and for the past two or three years the school management has been urging the Department to provide new equipment as the present lighting system is unsatisfactory. The Beauval School is wired for electricity and the electric plant at present in use is being operated by water power.

Although several letters have been written both to the Indian Agent and to the principal we have been unable to secure sufficiently definite information regarding exactly what is required to improve the lighting system at this school. I understand that we
should have information regarding the present capacity of the lighting plant and the additional amount of electricity required. It is also important to know if the head of water in the lake is sufficient to operate the plant which the school management has been requesting the Department to supply.

I believe it is advisable to have a competent person visit this school and report fully on what is required and I would appreciate if you would arrange to have one of your officers go to Beauval at an early date for that purpose.

I understand that he can fly from Prince Albert. I am informed that there is open water at Beauval about May 15.

Director.
This plant is entirely too small for the load connected, and could not be used in conjunction with a new plant. At best it could be repaired and used as a standby in case of a shut-down in the new plant.

The dam at the proposed power site is of concrete, and quite suitable in its present condition for the proposed power development. A head of twenty feet can be obtained with a penstock three hundred and forty (340) feet in length and with this head, and the water available, the power required for the school can be developed.

There are 76,000 acre feet available with a one foot draw off and this amount of water would operate the plant for five years; or, if the lake should increase its elevation approximately two inches during the summer months, there would be sufficient water to operate the plant for one year and still maintain the present elevation.

The only doubtful factor is the possibility of freezing of the outlet at the lake, but Father Gagnon assured me that this did not happen, and the danger of this happening could be eliminated by deepening the channel.

I am satisfied that the hydro-electric plant would be the most satisfactory installation, and that the expense of operating and upkeep would be very small for this location.

As an alternative there is the Diesel electric plant. The cost of installing such a plant would be much less, approximately $5,000.00, but the cost of fuel at the plant makes this almost prohibitive. The cost of Diesel fuel at Prince Albert is about 2½ per gallon, and the cost of transportation to Beauval would be at least 10¢ per gallon. To this would be added the cost of non-returnable drums which would bring the cost of the oil to at least 35¢ per gallon winter transportation. This would be 50% higher in summer, or 45¢ per gallon. This would bring the cost of fuel to operate a Diesel plant twelve (12) hours a day to about $1,500.00 a year.

Another alternative is the steam plant. The cost of installation of such a plant would be higher than the Diesel and would require the services of an experienced man continually. The cost of operating this type of plant would be higher than the Diesel plant.

School and Chapel ........................................... 200 - 60 Watt lam

REPORT ON PROPOSED HYDRO ELECTRIC PLANT
AT BEAUVAL, SASKATCHEWAN.

Dear Sir,

I have been to Beauval, Saskatchewan and inspected the site of the proposed Hydro electric plant there.

The source of water supply for the proposed plant is Lac la Plonge, elevation 1476, with an area of approximately 120 square miles.

The supply of water to this lake is from surrounding muskeg and some small creeks. Some years ago this lake had its regular spring floods, but for the past three years, on account of the dry seasons experienced in the North, there has been no spring flood of any account. When the school authorities noticed this they constructed a dam at the only outlet, La Plonge Creek, to control the flow, and have been successful in maintaining the present elevation for the past few years.

No raise in the water level of the lake had been recorded this year up to June 2nd, but Father Gagnon claims that with some rain and warmer weather the water level of the lake should become somewhat higher this season.

I installed a gauge at the dam and they will take readings from time to time and report what is happening.

The approach to the outlet has a depth at present of at least three feet, and could easily be increased to four feet at small expense. This, I was assured, would be taken care of by the school authorities. The dam at the outlet is well constructed - concrete piers in the main stream with earth approach, and the flow to the creek is controlled by a well constructed sluice gate. Conditions at the present time would allow at least one foot of water to be drawn from the lake. Beauval Residential School is situated on La Plonge Creek about four and one-half miles downstream from Lac la Plonge, and the school has constructed a second dam to form a suitable fore-bay for the operation of the present plant.

The present plant consists of a small vertical type water wheel belted to a 3Kw. D.C. generator operating at a head of fourteen feet; there is no governor to control the speed, the voltage being very irregular, and the lights poor.

This plant ..........

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Beauval Indian Residential School.

There are certain points relative to the proposed hydro-electric installation at the above School which should be cleared up before the equipment is purchased. The specifications have been completed and a requisition has been sent to the Purchasing Agent asking him to call for quotations.

The use of water from Lac la Plonge and from the La Plonge Creek for hydro-electric purposes would, if the project were entirely new, be subject to the approval of the Natural Resources Department of the Province of Saskatchewan. It is noted, however, that a dam was constructed some time ago at the lake outlet and that the School has already constructed another dam, with forebay, on La Plonge Creek in the vicinity of the School buildings. Will you kindly advise me if any authority was obtained from the Province for the erection of these two dams and under what financial arrangements they were erected. If the dam at Lac la Plonge was erected prior to the transfer of natural resources, the School authorities may have obtained the permission of the Federal Government, although there are no records in this connection in our Dominion Water Power Bureau.

The estimated cost of the list of equipment contained in Mr. Smith's report, exclusive of motors, is $9,150. It is noted that no specific mention is made of the cost of the necessary surge tank and if this has not
included in Mr. Smith's estimate, the estimated cost, at the present time, would approximate $9,500. However, Mr. Smith's estimated cost for the wood stave penstock seems liberal and possibly the cost of the surge tank is included in this figure.

While Mr. Smith mentions in his report that Father Gagnon assured him that the School would supply all labour and material for the foundation work, laying of penstock, etc., and in fact all labour required, I think it essential that you communicate with the School authorities and have confirmation of this arrangement in writing. Father Gagnon should be advised that the work to be done will include the installation and erection of all equipment, including turbine, generator, penstock, etc., and that this represents a very considerable amount of labour, some of which must be highly skilled, particularly in regard to the installation of turbine, generator, switchboard, etc. We will arrange to supply an Engineer to supervise the installation and will expect the School to provide him with board and accommodation. According to our understanding, all other assistance, including foreman, skilled labour and common labour, together with necessary construction equipment, will be furnished by the School authorities. A suitable hand-operated derrick or crane will be necessary to handle the heavy castings of the turbine and the generator, etc.

It would be appreciated if you would communicate with Father Gagnon on the above points as these matters should be definitely settled before any order is placed.

It is noted that the Department will assume the cost of freighting the equipment from Big River to Beauval and which will be undertaken in the winter months.

Director.
Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School

On receipt of your memorandum of November 18 with reference to the proposed hydro electric installation at the above school I immediately wrote to the Principal.

I am now in receipt of the following reply dated December 10, 1938:

"I am sorry, I could not answer your letter of the 24th ultimo any sooner, for the simple fact that after freeze up, the first mail was received only on the 6th of December. However, wishing to co-operate with you to install the new hydro electric plant in Beauval, I am giving you the following information:

"1. Dams.

The first dam, on the La Plonge Creek, with a forebay was constructed in 1904, by the Beauval R.C. Mission, therefore having the rights of the first occupant.

The second at the outlet of La Plonge Lake was erected in 1935 with the authority of C.J. McGavin, chief engineer of Water Rights, Department of Natural Resources, of Regina, Sask. This dam as well as the first one was erected by the R.C. Mission at Beauval and all expenses were paid by the said Mission. The use of the..."
dams will be for the school. Therefore, there will never be any trouble arising from it. This is a friendly co-operation between the Church and the Indian Affairs Branch.

2. New electric plant.

The report made by Mr. E. Smith is O.K. The management of the school is ready to co-operate with the Indian Affairs Branch for the construction as well as for the installation of this plant.

The school will provide the engineer with board and accommodation. I would appreciate very much, if Mr. E. Smith would be given a chance to come and supervise the work.

Also, the school will provide foreman, skilled labour, common labour, together with the necessary construction equipment, including a suitable hand-operated derrick.

Once more, I take the liberty to thank you very much for your co-operation in making it possible to have a new electric plant in Beauval, which was badly needed since the destruction of the former shop."

I trust that the above is the information you require and that immediate arrangements will be made to purchase the equipment in order that it may be shipped to the school early in 1939 which will permit us to pay for it out of the current fiscal year's appropriation.

6th July, 1943.

I beg to submit my report on the reserves of treaty 10 and treaty trip made to those reserves during the month of June, 1943.

Beauval Indian Residential School

A day was spent at this school and, as usual, everything was in the best of order. The children are healthy, happy and receiving an excellent training for their future lives. There are the very best kind of teachers in the three class rooms and the children make wonderful progress under their tuition. The writing, reading and rapid calculation of the boys in the older room would put most white boys to shame; the other rooms are almost equally good. The school has a large herd of well-bred Shorthorn cattle, which are used for both meat and dairy products. There is milk and butter in abundance for the use of the children. A large garden provides vegetables throughout the year. The school farm produces wheat, oats and barley, all used on the premises. The oats and barley for cattle and hog feed and the wheat for feed and for making flour, which is done on the premises with a flour mill operated by the school. The whole management of this school reflects honour upon the Principal, Reverend Father Gagnon.

Father Gagnon is a great missionary, but he is, in addition, a great business man, with vision and imagination, willing to try anything which promises to promote the best interests of the school and the welfare of the Indian children. A large herd of cattle, hogs and horses receive daily care by the Indian boys, who also assist in operating the flour-mill, saw-mill and all farm machinery, in season. The lighting plant is operated by water-power, as is also the saw-mill, and the cost of operation of each is almost nothing. There is a large flock of chickens which keep the school supplied with fresh eggs. These, also, are under the care of the boys of the school.

The girls are taught cooking, baking, sewing, knitting, carding, spinning and weaving, as well as bead-work and silk work for ornaments of their own choosing. I notice an air of happiness and good will amongst the children and between the children and the school staff, which speaks well.
of their relationship at all times.

The school buildings are in good repair. The main school building is almost completely fire-proof. An evidence of this is shown by the fact that lightning struck the school last year and came into one of the rooms at night. The scorched wall was found in the morning and can still be seen, but no fire resulted.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School

This Branch has just been advised by the Principal of the above-mentioned school that, due to low water in La Plonge River during the past two winters, the river has frozen solid. Re: Beauval Indian Residential School.

With reference to your memorandum of May 18th and on looking over our files in this matter, it would appear from an earlier report of Mr. E. Mr. Smith reported that the approach to the outlet of the lake where there is a dam had a depth of only 3 or 4 feet. He considered that conditions would permit of, at least, one foot of water being drawn from the lake. He made no report on the 4½ miles of creek between the outlet of the lake and the school.

Mr. Smith foresaw the possibility of trouble arising from freezing at the outlet of the lake but Father Gagnon assured him that this did not happen.

During the past three winters the power for the School and Mission has been generated from a belt connection to a diesel tractor which the mission have on hand. I understand from Father Cegnon that this was barely satisfactory and involved a number of difficulties other than depriving the mission of the use of the tractor. The domestic supply during the first two of the last three years was obtained by hauling it from a spring located below the pump house. Lac Winter's concrete well was constructed into which the spring flowed, and the water was pumped from there to the storage tank at the school. This tank has a capacity of 2000 gallons and in case of fire, this arrangement would not be adequate; also there is evidence at present of the spring drying up to some slight extent.

Dismissing the idea of piping the water from above the upper control dam as either too costly or not dependable, there appears to be only two other solutions to the situation which has developed.

There is the possibility of creating a reservoir above the power dam with sufficient pondage to operate the power unit and meet domestic requirements during the four months when the supply from Lac Le Plonge is cut off. I do not believe it would be good policy to raise the level at the present dam with this in mind. This scheme, therefore, even if otherwise practical, would involve the prospect of building another dam, also the water thus impounded may not prove suitable for domestic supply.

The only scheme that seems practical and which the writer would recommend at the present time, would be the installation of a diesel unit. While the transportation difficulties that exist here would make the problem of bringing in fuel rather expensive, it would only be necessary to resort to this source of power for four months of the year. The diesel would also be on hand for emergency operation during other periods. The problem of domestic supply during the winter months, while barely adequate, could be managed. There is also a good prospect of the situation remedying itself later.

I have secured all the necessary field data required for the plans in connection with the issuing of a Provincial License, and will send the plans as soon as they are completed.

Re - Investigation Beausel Indian Residential School.

The situation that currently exists during the winter months at the Beausel School and Mission is a lack of water for both the domestic requirements and the hydroelectric development. This situation has existed for the past three winters, and has been caused by freezing at the outlet of Lac Le Plonge, thus cutting off the water which previously found its way down River Le-Plonge.

The freezing is by no means a purely local condition and occurs not only at the outlet, but also for some considerable distance out into the lake. The freezing usually commences several hundred feet out from the outlet and gradually works in to the control dam which is approximately quarter of a mile down the river from its junction with the lake.

These conditions did not exist until three years ago, up until which time the water in Lac Le Plonge was at least 2½ feet higher than it is at present. As a result of this lower water level there is now no depth of water greater than 2½ feet within 1500 feet of the outlet into River Le Plonge with the result that this whole area freezes solid during the cold weather. It is not a case of a sandbar or other obstruction impeding the flow and alterations in the construction at the control dam would not remedy the situation. The lowering of Lac Le Plonge can in no way be attributed to the negligible amount of water which is allowed through the control dam down River Le Plonge, as the sluice gate at the control dam is kept constantly closed except in the spring and on the other brief periods during which the sawmill is in operation. River Le-Plonge has a few small feeder streams and these supply sufficient water for both power and domestic supply. They cannot, however, be depended upon during the cold weather or very dry seasons.

The only remedy the writer could suggest for this freezing condition would be to pipe the water from the deeper portion of the lake past the upper control dam to a point where the bed of the river assumes a gradient sufficient to allow the water to flow freely. The upper section of River Le Plonge in the vicinity of the control dam is, in places not less than 5 feet wide and one foot deep. This remedy would not, in my opinion, be a very feasible engineering operation. It would require a minimum of $2000 for the pipe and disregarding the difficulties involved and expense attached to such an undertaking, there is no assurance that the level of Lac Le Plonge will not recede still farther, thus rendering the scheme useless. Lac Le Plonge has not a large drainage area, and forest fires in recent years have exposed most of the surrounding country. This may account partially for the lowering in the lake level, although precipitation in this district during the past three years has been subnormal. As an alternative to laying a pipe, there would be the prospect of digging an open channel out to deeper water. It would be impractical to attempt this without equipment which I am certain could not be brought in to this location.
Memorandum:

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School

In reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum of July 20th last regarding the water supply at the above school, we are attaching two copies of a report prepared by Mr. K. B. André following an inspection made during the period August 11th to 18th, 1944.

Mr. André states that until three years ago, the level of Lac La Plonge was at least 2½ feet higher than at present, and that there is now no depth of water greater than 2½ feet within 1500 feet of the outlet into La Plonge river. This area freezes solid to the bottom in winter cutting off the flow to the river and to the hydro-electric plant.

The lowering of the lake level is said to be due to sub-normal rainfall and not to any wasteful operation of the control dam, as the sluice is only opened when the sawmill is being operated and in winter. At other times there is a sufficient flow from some small streams entering the river below the control dam, but these cannot be depended on in cold weather or very dry seasons.

The excavation of a channel to deeper water in the lake is not feasible owing to the expense involved and the difficulty of taking suitable equipment over the road from Meadow Lake to Beauval, nor does the raising of the dam at the power plant to create sufficient storage to operate during the winter appear to be an attractive proposition.

During the past three winters when this low water condition has obtained the school authorities have operated the generator by a belt drive from their Diesel tractor. In this way they were able to carry on, but at the loss of the use of the tractor for other purposes.

Under the circumstances, Mr. André recommends that a Diesel engine be installed to operate the generator when the water supply is insufficient during the winter or in emergencies during other periods. We concur in this recommendation, and would suggest that, as was done at the McIntosh school when the penstock was being replaced, a used truck or automobile engine together with the necessary pulleys and belting be purchased, and installed by the school authorities. At McIntosh, the Department paid $60.00 for the pulleys and belting, and $100.00 for a used automobile engine. The school purchased the engine and installed it.

Re: Lighting plant for the Beauval School

Attention Mr. Phelan

My dear Mr. Phelan,

You will no doubt remember the request made by His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse for an auxiliary lighting plant for the above school.

Due to the lower water levels which have now prevailed for several years in the Beauval region the hydro-electric plant of the school is in service for only a few months every year and has to be supplemented by a gasoline or crude oil operated plant. Your suggestion that a second hand automobile motor and generator be purchased and installed to meet the deficiencies of the hydro plant has been considered and found inadequate besides being expensive to operate. It must not be forgotten that discarded automobile motors are all gasoline operated and, on that account, their cost of maintenance is very high. At best, they are only a makeshift. The case of McIntosh to which you refer in your letter cannot be compared to that of Beauval because in the former the interruption in the Hydro service was very temporary as it only lasted a little over two weeks.

The Beauval situation is quite different because the low water level has now occurred every winter for the past several years and nothing indicates that there will be a change in these conditions in the near future. Consequently, what we have to provide for Beauval is an auxiliary plant on which the school can depend and which will be economical in operation. Only a Diesel power plant can meet these requirements and we sincerely hope that you will consider its purchase favorably. I am sending a copy of this letter to His Exe., Bishop Lajeunesse and you may consider the present request as coming from him personally.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Frigidaire Condensing Units
Air Cooled Models AF375, AF4100, AF5150

Frigidaire Condensing Units are available in a range of sizes to meet every commercial refrigeration need. Features listed below combine to produce maximum refrigeration capacity at a minimum operating cost.

Compressor—Two cylinder, slow speed, vertical, single acting, reciprocating type.

Service Valves—Two-way type with outlet provided for gauge connection. Integral with cylinder head on the Model AF375. Large forged brass valves are used on the Model AF4100. A large forged brass discharge valve and a malleable iron suction valve are employed on the Model AF5150.

Fin and Tube Condenser—Steel fin and tube (radiator type) condenser for rapid heat dissipation. Dual fans of special design, motor fan and auxiliary fan (which is fixed on a bracket brazed to the condenser and powered through a small V-belt), direct a maximum air flow through the large condenser surface to assure economical operation.

Receiver—Horizontal, steel shell type receiver. Large liquid capacity. Equipped with fusible plug and liquid line valve.

Liquid Strainer—Fine mesh metal screens filter all liquid refrigerant.

Lubrication—Adequate lubrication for all moving parts is supplied by oil splash. Large oil wells on top of main bearings supply oil continuously to the bearings.

Flywheel—High strength cast iron, statically balanced.

Drive—Multiple cog-type V-belts provide a positive and efficient drive. Flywheel, pulleys, belts and fans are protected by the condenser shroud.

Condensing Unit Base—Heavy, one-piece, all steel, welded construction assures rigid support for entire assembly.

Finish—Condensing Unit finished in black baked enamel.

"Frigilube" Oil—Special 150 viscosity oil, refined to Frigidaire specifications. A positive lubricant that never "wears out."

**FRIGIDAIRE "MOISTEMP"**

*Designed and Built by Frigidaire for Matched Operation as a Unit*

Frigidaire "Moistemp" gravity type cooling units are designed to provide proper moisture conditions as well as correct temperatures. To accomplish this, Frigidaire engineers developed an exclusive design which permits operation at higher temperatures, thereby decreasing moisture removal from the air.

The design of the "Moistemp" cooling units provide extra fin surface at the top where warm air first comes in contact with the fins. This is accomplished through the use of exclusive diamond shaped fins which eliminate all ineffective heat absorbing surface.

Automatic defrosting during the off period of the compressor is improved due to reduced fin surface at the bottom of the cooling unit, the point where ice or frost accumulation is usually experienced. The shape of the fin with the diamond points downward also aids in faster frost removal from the fins during the defrosting cycle. An additional defrosting aid results due to improved air circulation through the cooling unit.

The operating efficiency of the Frigidaire "Moistemp" cooling units is further improved by the use of the "wet expansion" principle of refrigeration. This method assures the entire internal refrigerant tube surface being "wet" with liquid refrigerant, thus insuring unusual efficiency in heat removal and economical operation.

FRIGIDAIRE "MOISTEMP" COOLING UNIT FEATURES

Refrigerant Distribution Wells—Efficient manifold design assures complete and uniform distribution of refrigerant throughout the tubes. The ends of tubes are joined to upper and lower manifolds, resulting in a maximum tube area being in contact with liquid refrigerant at all times. This "wet expansion" principle increases capacity and provides uniform cooling unit temperature as well as lower operating cost. A special baffle in the upper manifold increases heat absorbing ability by maintaining cooling unit in a flooded condition. Baffle feature also reduces possibility of refrigerant line sweating.

Multiple Tube Construction—Refrigerant travel is through several individual tubes rather than one continuous tube. Cooling is faster because less time is required for heat laden refrigerant to pass through the cooling unit to the compressor.

Corrosion-Resisting Tubing—3/4" copper tubing is used to give faster cooling. Electro tin plated to prevent corrosion. Larger diameter of tube reduces frictional pressure drop and improves overall efficiency of the cooling unit. All units are thoroughly cleaned, dehydrated, and sealed to remove moisture and foreign matter which later would affect operation of control valves.

Silver-Soldered Joints—Only silver solder is used on the refrigerant joints of the gravity type cooling units to eliminate the possibility of leaks due to corrosion or electrolytic decomposition. Silver-soldered joints have proved to be stronger than the copper tubing itself.

Improved Circulation—Proper air circulation through the cooling unit is provided by adequate spacing between fin rows. This prevents choking of air circulation and improves the operating efficiency of the cooling unit. Defrosting is also aided by the larger volume of air in contact with the colder, lower portion of the fin.

Hydraulic Tube Expansion—A tight metal-to-metal bond between the copper tube and fin is obtained by hydraulically expanding the refrigerant tube into the "Effect-fin." This positive bond assures rapid heat transfer from the fin to the refrigerant filled tube.

In addition to the "Moistemp" Gravity Air Type Cooling Units, Frigidaire also offers a complete line of "Moistemp" Forced Air Cooling Units ranging in capacity from 60 pounds to 8 tons of refrigeration per day.

MEMORANDUM:

November 19, 1945.

Re: Refrigeration Plant for Beauval Indian Residential School.

In accordance with the request from the Director of Indian Affairs in his memorandum to you under date of November 9th, 1945, we are forwarding herewith, six copies of a specification covering the proposed refrigeration plant for the above, for the use of the Departmental Purchasing Agent, in obtaining tenders.

It is pointed out that if such a plant had been visualized when the building was originally planned, a more convenient location of the Walk-in Cooler Room could have been obtained.

Under the circumstances there appears to be no alternative to using the space suggested. The mechanical unit of the installation however, must occupy space outside of the refrigerator and it is suggested that a corner of the Pantry near the outside wall, be cleared and used for this purpose.

From data submitted in the memorandum, it is evident that a unit having approximately 1 ton of refrigeration capacity will be necessary. This would require a 1 or 2 horsepower motor, depending on the design of the equipment.

This specification calls for the equipment to be based on the following operating conditions: maintain an inside temperature of 35 degrees F. with an ambient temperature of 85 degrees F. and 80 degrees F. condensing water, the accepted standard for this type of work.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
1. SCOPE OF WORK:

This Specification is intended to cover the supply and installation of a complete Refrigeration Plant for a Walk-in Cooler Room which is located in an allotted space in the Basement. This equipment shall include a Condensing Unit, Cooling Coils, Piping, Drainage, Automatic Controls, etc. Machine capacities shall be determined on an operating time of not more than 16 hours per 24 hours, so as to permit a proper defrosting cycle.

The approximate dimensions of the room to be converted into the Walk-in Cooler Room are 12'-6" x 25'-6" x 9'-0". The Department, however, accepts no responsibility for the accuracy of same. It shall be the duty of the Contractor to visit the Building and take all necessary measurements and provide himself with all the necessary data required to enable him to submit a tender.

The Contractor shall also make all structural and piping changes, additions to the room, etc., as hereinafter specified or as may be required. He will be held responsible for all the above work as well as the provision of equipment of suitable capacity and performance to maintain conditions as specified.

2. ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS:

The Contractor shall remove existing window sash and frame and shall brick up the opening. He shall also remove the radiator from this room and cap the steam supply and return connections near the mains.

All steam and return piping including branches to upper floor radiators shall be stripped of their present covering and shall be re-covered as follows:- All pipes to have 4 ply 1" thick asbestos air cell covering, carefully butted and fitted around hangers where such occur. In addition these pipes shall be covered with 1" thick anti-sweat wool felt sectional covering consisting of two ½" layers, each of which shall have been so fabricated by its manufacturer as to have a double thickness of asphalt paper both inside and out, stapled in place, and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on.

The Contractor shall provide and set in place stud partitions, full height, sheathed both sides, dividing the room into 3 compartments. Floor, ceiling, and inner side of enclosing walls, (not including new partitions) shall have 2 layers of insulating cork not less than 2" thick laid with staggered, vertical, tight joints, over a layer of water and vapour proof paper having joints lapped at least 3". "Pulco" wool will be acceptable as an alternative to cork insulation.

If the existing floor is wood, it shall be removed and replaced by a 4" reinforced concrete floor, using 18 gauge reinforcing wire mesh and a 1" finish trowelled smooth.
