The Contractor shall provide and set in place 3 standard type refrigerator doors, complete with approved hardware including hasp and padlock and an approved refrigerator door closer. These doors shall be located to provide separate entry into each of the 3 compartments, and shall be located in the wall adjoining the hall.

3. **CONDENSING UNIT**

The complete assembly of the Condensing Unit shall include an air or water cooled compressor of the required capacity, with line valves, approved motor with thermal overload protection, V belt drive with safety guard, low pressure control and liquid line strainer, all mounted on a heavy integral cast iron base. Supply one quart of lubricating oil for this unit.

4. **SETTING**

The Condensing Unit shall be firmly set where directed in the Pantry, on a 6" concrete sub base with suitable insulating pads between the base of the unit and the concrete sub base.

5. **COOLING COILS**

The Contractor shall furnish and install at the ceiling or on the walls, (with suitable baffles if required) in the Walk-in Cooler Room, suitable finned type cooling coils suspended in an approved manner, complete with drip pans, drip piping and approved automatic control equipment especially suited to the requirements.

6. **PIPING**

The Contractor shall provide and erect all necessary piping and connections as may be required, and the whole system shall be fully charged with "Freon" or "Methyl Chloride", depending upon the equipment used. He shall also make all necessary water and drainage connections as may be required. The equipment shall be placed in operation and thoroughly tested for workmanship and performance.

7. **ELECTRICAL CONNECTIONS**

The Contractor shall supply automatic re-set and overload protection, and pressure switch motor control for the unit. Electric power shall be taken from the nearest convenient source, the power available being 3 phase, 220 volts 60 cycles A.C. The unit shall be connected up in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and all wiring shall be done in conformity with the C.E.S.A. Code. Ground all equipment to the Code Specification.

8. **LIGHTING**

The Contractor shall disconnect and remove the existing lighting fixtures, switches, and any exposed conduit or wiring in the space to be converted into a Walk-in Cooler Room.

Provide and install in each of the 3 compartments of the Walk-in Cooler Room, one lighting outlet located at ceiling. Provide and install vapour-tight fixtures with globes, equal to Crouse-Hinds series V, and include 100 watt, 1000 hour, 115 volt Mazda quality inside frosted lamps for each outlet.

Wiring shall be run in rigid conduit on ceiling from nearest panel having sufficient capacity. Where conduit enters refrigerated compartments it shall be run in lead conduit provided with a tight seal at point of entry to compartment.
Provide adjacent to each door, one plate switch for each light, provided with ruby bulls-eye pilot light arranged to indicate when light is "on".

All wiring is to be carried out to the C.E.S.A. Code and grounded to Code Specification.

9. CONTRACTOR'S SPECIFICATION:

The capacity of the plant shall be based upon maintaining an inside temperature of 35 degrees F. in the Walk-in Cooler Room with an ambient temperature of 65 degrees F. and 80 degrees F. condensing water. The Contractor whose tender is accepted shall submit drawings giving dimensions and full details of the equipment he proposes to install, and no work shall be done on the installation until such drawings and details have been approved and authority for operations have been issued by the Department.

10. GUARANTEE:

The Contractor shall furnish a guarantee of satisfactory performance and mechanical adequacy for a period of 12 months from the date of acceptance by the Department. Should any fault due to inferior workmanship or material become evident in that time, the Contractor shall rectify such fault, without expense to the Department as soon as possible after being notified in writing that such faults have appeared.
Ottawa, November 21st, 1945.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Re: Refrigeration Plant for Beauval Indian Residential School.

I desire to refer you to your memorandum of March 11 and previous correspondence in connection with the above.

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, May 1, 1946.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is prepared to supply refrigeration equipment at the Beauval Residential School, but additional information is necessary.

Kindly let me know the type of electric current available at your school. You should state the voltage and, if it is alternating current, you should state the frequency.

I understand the electric power at your school is generated through the use of batteries, and you should let me know the type and size of the battery at present in use. Possibly you would operate the refrigeration unit with a special machine. If so, you should let me have full particulars regarding the type of machine which you intend to use.

An immediate reply would be appreciated, in order that the placing of the order will not be unnecessarily delayed.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Beauval, Sask.
Indian Residential School,

Mr. Philip Phelan:

File: 132-1-5 Letter May 1 1946.

Dear Sir:

I am very pleased to hear that the Department will supply refrigeration equipment at the Beauval School and I am also glad to give you the information.

Where we want to put the Frigidaire, the electric current is alternating current, 110-220 volts, 60 cycle.

We are not using batteries, as the turbine supply us a 24 hour service and the generator is a 25 kilowatts.

The motor to drive this frigidaire should be 220 volts, 60 cycle with automatic switch and starter.

I hope this is the information required in your letter.

May thanks for the attention given to my request.

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal.

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, June 6, 1946.

Dear Father Gagnon:

Reverend Father Plourde advises me that you still require another engine as an auxiliary unit for the lighting plant at the Beauval School. You will recall that we had considerable correspondence about this matter during 1945, but at that time we were unable to secure the equipment desired. As I have not heard directly from you about the matter since receipt of your letter of July 6, 1945, I was hopeful that conditions had improved. However, from my conversation with Father Plourde, it appears that this is not the case.

The equipment required for your school is still difficult to obtain. However, it is possible that we may be able to secure it, but before requesting our Departmental Purchasing Agent to act in the matter, I thought it advisable to again write to you.

We recently purchased an auxiliary unit for the Grass Lake School, as follows:

1 only Diesel Engine, twin cylinder, overhead valves, developing 16 H.P. at 1200 R.P.M., the Lister C.E. or equal, tank cooled model, fuel tank capacity 7 gallons, bore X stroke 4\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 4-3/8", Flywheel dia. X face 23" x 3\(\frac{1}{2}\)", Pulley X Face 10" x 9", water tank capacity 170 gallons, water tank dia. X height 30" x 66".

Please let me know as soon as possible if the engine mentioned above, or equal, would be suitable for your requirements.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Beauval, Sask.

Dear Sir:

I have just received yours of the 6th instant regarding the auxiliary unit for the lighting plant at the Beauval School.

Unfortunately, this equipment is still required and will be for some time, according to the weather.

I think that the auxiliary unit supplied to the Gross Lake School would be a little small for our need. I would prefer one 20 or 25 H.P. if possible. If not possible to get the above, well I think we will have to satisfy ourselves with the 16 H.P. mentioned in your letter.

For the other specifications, it would be all right except the pulley, as the generator pulley is for V belts.

I just received a copy of a letter from Mr. Bernard F. Neary, Supt. of Welfare & Training about the requisition.

As to the inquiry about the washing Machines, I have already forwarded to you the invoice as I could not wait any more. The machines were all fallen into pieces.

As to the household range required, something like the one found in Eaton's Catalogue from Winnipeg, fall and winter 1946-47. Cat. no 56-L124 the Marlboro, Wood Firebox type or even Cat. no. 56-L26 - Master Climax for wood - or by the enclosed leaf of the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co. Limited.

I know also that it has not been the practice to supply a potato peeler. But I think you will admit with me that little girls who have to spend an hour or so peeling potatoes, would be better playing outside in the open air or be employed in more important work where they could learn more.

The Indians in their grievances are mentioning that their children are doing too much chore work so I thought that a potato peeler would help in this line to improve things a little and with my own experience I have notice that it is not advisable to have local help for the chore work. It is ordinary a great source of troubles.

Hoping that my request will be taken into consideration,

I am,

Yours very truly,

"F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I."

Dear Sir,

File 132-1-5 (W.T.1)
Re: Purchase Order no. 11211.

Last January, you inquired about the refrigeration unit which was ordered for this school on May 23, 1946.

In May of this year, I have received the unit with the exception of two items: The 1 H.P. electric motor and the automatic switch which were missing.

Since I have notified the Keyes Co. Ltd of Ottawa and they pretend to have shipped the unit all complete and they also mentioned that if these two things are missing I would have to inquire with the Transportation Companies, which I did but without any results.

This motor was supposed to be bolted on the unit with the automatic switch. Instead, we found only one fan bolted on the unit where the motor was supposed to be bolted on. I have mentioned this to the Company but I did not have their answer yet.

On the purchase order, the electric motor is mentioned but on their invoice, there is no mention of same. So far, I have not queried the invoice. I frankly believe that the motor has not been shipped as they claim, because the paint shows absolutely no sign of a motor being bolted on this unit.

I have received only last month the instructions as to install same, and I notice that the dimensions mentioned are far from being the ones I have asked for.

"Two adjoining rooms are to be erected each measuring approximately 4 x 6' in floor space with a ceiling of 8'."

The dimensions I had suggested for the room that was available was: The freezing room height 9'9" x length 13' and width 12½'. The cooling room adjoining: 9'9", length 10', width 12½'. You will see the difference.

to be continued.
Mr. Bernard Neary. Re Purchase order no.11211.

So today, I am quite doubtful if I should go into the expenses of erecting this frigidaire, as I do not think it will be satisfactory. Such a small frigidaire for a school of 100 pupils and so far away from rails, 116 miles, where we have to store meat, fish and vegetables.

I would not have dared to mention this if it had not been for the Dietitian at Lebret who is reported having said that she was to recommend to the Indian Affairs Branch to have large frigidaire installed in the schools according to locations.

I think this remark would apply to this school as large amount of food have to be stored for months on account of great distances from supply houses.

May I mention also, that we raise all the vegetables needed for the whole year. We have also enough berries locally; blueberries, strawberries and raspberries; we also have our meat, beef and pork, but the only drawback is to keep all that food stuff the whole year around. I think you will admit with me that a larger frigidaire would be needed here to give a well balanced diet to the children.

So before going ahead with this frigidaire I will wait for your decision.

Thanking you in advance for your kindness.

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal.

Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir:

File: 132-1-5.

I have yours of the 13th instant regarding the refrigerating unit purchased by the Department for the Beauval Residential School.

This unit was received in May and as it was not complete, I have notified the company about it advising them that I could not sign the invoice unless it was complete.

At that time, the electric Motor 1H.F.A.C. 110/220 volt, 60 cycle with automatic switch with the instructions regarding the erecting, insulation, finishing of the cold rooms and also instructions as to the installation and operation of this equipment. Since, I have received the instructions, but the motor and automatic switch is still missing.

Furthermore, all the copper tubing is missing, but this item is not mentioned in the purchase order.

The electric motor and the switch was supposed to be mounted on the unit and the Company Keyes Supply pretended that something had happened on the way and that we had to put a claim at the transportation companies. After a close check, we see that no motor has been bolted on the unit, as there no mark on the paint.

On August the 11th, The Keyes Supply Co. have mentioned in their letter: "We are trying to trace the missing motor from the shipment of refrigeration equipment that was made some time ago.

Unfortunately, we cannot give you an immediate answer as to what happened but you may rest assured we will do everything possible to see that you receive this motor as soon as we find out exactly what happened."

This is about a resume of the correspondence I had with the Company about the missing articles.

Over.
After I received the instructions regarding the erection, insulation and finishing of the cold storage rooms, I was a little surprised at the size of the rooms. I quote:

"Two adjoining rooms are to be erected each measuring approximately 4x6' in floor space with a ceiling height of 8'."

When I saw that these rooms were so small and far from being the dimensions given in request to the Department, I again asked the Company if their refrigeration unit they had sent me could be used for larger storage rooms and here is the answer.

"We note that you intend to use two rooms of quite a size and these rooms do not agree with the original size of rooms for which the equipment was specified. The cooling room you mention is 10' x 12' 6", would require the machine which you received, plus another cooling unit to handle this room alone. The freezer which you mention, being 13' x 12' 6" would require an air cooled machine and would be best served by an electric defrost type blast cooler.

We are sorry to advise that the machine you received is not capable of handling both these rooms and as such, some decision will have to be reached before work is progressed too far".

I think the above is self explanatory. If I have been communicating direct with the firm, it is because I thought it was up to me now to see that everything be O.K. before signing the invoice and as to the size of the rooms, I also did it on good faith to spare you more troubles.

As I can see it now from your letter, there must have been a mistake somewhere about dimensions of storage rooms. I had given the freezing room dimensions as for two rooms, one for fish and the other for meat and also the dimensions for the cooling room. Any way just now I hesitate in going into the expenses of putting such a small storage rooms which I think will not be satisfactory for the amount of peoples here and the amount of food stuffs to be stored owing to the great distances from the rails, specially after the recommendations made by the diatitian made the cooks at the Lebret school this summer.

I hope you will understand my position and I am sorry to give you so much trouble but I would like to do things right.

Yours very truly:

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The Beauval Indian Residential School is a fireproof building. The floors and walls are either of cement or brick. Unfortunately, the interior, with the exception of a few rooms was never plastered.

The principal is very anxious to have the plastering done during the coming fiscal year. The estimates vary from fifteen to twenty thousand dollars and I therefore ask that this amount be placed in the 1949-1950 estimates.

1: The floors in the whole school were never well finished and offer a sorry sight to any visitor. The Principal desires to cover them with linoleum and he would appreciate that a large quantity of some kind of linoleum be supplied during the coming year. Personally, I think that you should begin by supplying five hundred yards of linoleum. I leave the color and kind to your good taste. The kitchen floor is in a very poor condition and he would like to have, immediately, a sufficient quantity of tile to cover it. This kitchen measures 24' x 40'. Any color of tile would do but he would prefer that it be of the color of white marble.

2: The oven now in use is a "Daoust" model and is almost completely worn out. As the pupilage is over one hundred, he would like to have a new oven with hundred loaves capacity. This oven should be supplied, if at all possible to do so, in the very near future.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Canadian Westinghouse Co. Ltd. giving me some quotation on a voltage regulator which would be very useful to our electric plant here.

The school electric plant consists of a 25 kilowatts generator with a water turbine and an oil governor. The function of the oil governor is to open the gates or to close them, depending on the amount of power required to start a motor or when more lights are required. Thus regulating the amount of water required to maintain the same voltage.

This oil governor is working well but is too slow; starting a motor or using electric welder brings the light very low, thus making it quite hard on the eyes and also on electric motors if too slow to start. Furthermore, the stopping of a motor or cutting lots of lights at the same time causes the voltage to raise, thus burning the lights. I am using a big case of lights every month.

After many consultations with electricians, I was told that the only way to overcome this would be to install a voltage regulator to draw the right amount of voltage as required by the sudden overcharge.

With the nice plant we have, I think it advisable to add this improvement. Therefore, I am asking you to recommend this purchasing of this voltage regulator to the Indian Affairs Branch to complete the unit and as an electrician will be on the spot next summer, it would be the right time to have this regulator installed.

Hoping to have an early and favourable answer.

Yours very truly, sgd. F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I.

Indian Residential School,
Beauval Sask.,
October 4, 1949.

Dear Sir:

Since the 1950-51 estimates for the Beauval Indian Residential School have been forwarded to Ottawa through the regular channel, I have discovered something that will give trouble in the near future. Being authorized by His Excellency Martin Lajeunesse and Mr. J.A. Davis, Supt., of the Meadow Lake agency I have decided to write you direct in order to save time.

The Principal's or Fathers' house:
This house, formerly a student's house, was built by the Episcopal Corporation of Kashegan. The first floor, in 1910 with two subsequent additions to it in form of a square, one part of the square is about 30' x 42' and the other part is about 26' x 48'. It is a frame building built on the sand without any foundation. The sills are rotten, which would mean that in order to jack it up, false beams would be required and I don't think that the building itself would stand as the walls are starting to bulge. Also brick siding would be required to make it more comfortable in winter time. This building would cost too much to be repaired and as it has the inconvenience of being 500 yards away from the school which means lots of walking back and forth to do our work, I believe it would be better to wreck it down and salvage all the lumber we can, to build a machine shed, which is greatly needed and also lot of material such as sinks, toilets, water pipes, radiators and furnitures could be used in the new building.

New Father's house required:
So instead of repairing this old house, I would suggest that an addition be added to the Indian Residential School to serve as the Principal's residence and offices. The present heating system of the Indian School could easily take care of these additions and it would mean great savings for fuel and labor and would also be more convenient.

Sketch:
For your convenience, I inclose a sketch showing the proposed additions to the Indian School. On the boys' side, full basement 30' x 42' inside measurements for toilets, urinals, bathrooms, dressing room, special room for the grown up boys and also cloak rooms.

On the first floor right above this basement would be the Fathers' residence as shown on the sketch.

On the girls' side, a full basement, 30' x 42', for toilets, shower baths, dressing rooms with a special room for the grown up girls.

Above would be two class rooms as I have to take the boys' and girls' infirmaries from the second floor to the first to give more room to the Sisters so using one actual class room as a girls' infirmary.

Building Material:
The Indian School is a fireproof building built with cement and bricks. I would like very much to have the additions built out of the same material.
As I have been advised by a Meadow Lake contractor, reinforcing steel will be hard to get next Summer and also the transportation of bricks would be pretty expensive. (Beauval School being 116 miles north of the end of rail and the roads are in bad conditions with no hope of getting them repaired in the near future. Winter time would be the best time to have some material transported to Beauval; it is cheaper and easier.)

So I would suggest a full cement basement, the height as the rest of the building and for the first floor wooden frame with brick sidings, one layer of asbestos paper, one layer of shiplap, rockwool or similar material in the walls and ceiling, 2x6 studs, with plastered Gyprock inside. The floor could be made of fireproof tiles. The roof gravel and tar. This would make it practically fireproof and quite warm.

I expect to be able to send you the estimates on the cost of labor and material in about ten days' time, in order to have the estimates figured for this coming fiscal year and have the material transported in Winter time.

If the sketch is not clear enough, although I am quite busy, I would be prepared to take a trip to Ottawa. In the meantime, I will appreciate an early reply to this request.

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Beauval Indian Residential School.

I have received Mr. Levy's memorandum of October 11 referring to a letter of October 4 sent to the Superintendent of Education.

Please find attached a copy of the letter sent by Father Gagnon, the Principal of this School. You will note that Father Gagnon is requesting the following changes to the Beauval Residential School:

(a) The dismantling of the present Principal's residence and its replacement by an addition of 30 by 42 ft., extending the boys' side of the school;

(b) A similar extension of 30 by 42 ft. to the girls' side of the school.

Both these additions would have full basements and extensive plumbing arrangements would be necessary. You will note also that both these additions will have to be made of cement and bricks, with reinforcing steel required also.

As this school is 116 miles north of the end of rail at Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, it would be necessary to have all these supplies shipped in during the winter. No funds are provided in our present Estimates for this project and it is the first intimation which we have had that such additions are required.

Therefore, before proceeding with Father Gagnon's
request, it will be necessary for us to take the following action:

(a) To have our Educational Survey Officer proceed to this school and submit an inspection report as to the need for these additions.

(b) If his report is favourable, then an engineer will have to be sent to prepare plans and specifications for the work outlined by Father Gagnon.

Our experience with similar requests has been that we must proceed cautiously and only upon professional advice.

You will note for example that Father Gagnon makes the following statement: "The present heating system of the Indian school could easily take (care) of these additions". We have heard similar statements made previously when additions to residential schools have been proposed by principals and church authorities. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Beauval Indian Residential School.

I have received Mr. Levy's memorandum of October 11 referring to a letter of October 4 sent to the Superintendent of Education.

Please find attached a copy of the letter sent by Father Gagnon, the Principal of this School. You will note that Father Gagnon is requesting the following changes to the Beauval Residential School:

(a) The dismantling of the present Principal's residence and its replacement by an addition of 30 by 42 ft. extending the boys' side of the school;

(b) A similar extension of 30 by 42 ft. to the girls' side of the school.

Both these additions would have full basements and extensive plumbing arrangements would be necessary. You will note also that both these additions will have to be made of cement and bricks, with reinforcing steel required also.

As this school is 116 miles north of the end of rail at Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, it would be necessary to have all these supplies shipped in during the winter. No funds are provided in our present Estimates for this project and it is the first intimation which we have had that such additions are required.

Therefore, before proceeding with Father Gagnon's
request, it will be necessary for us to take the following action:

(a) To have our Educational Survey Officer proceed to this school and submit an inspection report as to the need for these additions.

(b) If his report is favourable, then an engineer will have to be sent to prepare plans and specifications for the work outlined by Father Gagnon.

Our experience with similar requests has been that we must proceed cautiously and only upon professional advice.

You will note for example that Father Gagnon makes the following statement: "The present heating system of the Indian school could easily take (care) of these additions". We have heard similar statements made previously when additions to residential schools have been proposed by principals and church authorities. Usually some local furnace man is called in to advise on a heating problem which can only be handled by a professional engineer. In a year or two we are then advised that the new section of the building is cold and before long are faced with a heavy bill for the installation of an entire new heating system throughout the school.

Therefore I would recommend your approval of the action which I have indicated above before any further consideration is given to Father Gagnon's request.

Director.

October 4, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt., Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Since the 1950-51 estimates for the Beauval Indian Residential School have been forwarded to Ottawa through the regular channel, I have discovered something that will give trouble in the near future. Being authorized by His Excellency Martin Lajeunesse and Mr. J. A. Davis, Supt. of the Meadow Lake agency I have decided to write you direct in order to save time.

The Principal's or Father's house.

This house, formerly a student's house, was built by the Episcopal Corporation of Kewatin, The Pas, Man. in 1910 with two subsequent additions to it in form of a square, one part of the square is about 30' x 42' and the other part is about 26' x 45'. It is a frame building built on the sand without any foundation. The sills are rotten, which would mean that in order to jack it up, false beams would be required and I don't think that the building itself would stand it as the walls are starting to bulge. Also brick siding would be required to make it more comfortable in winter time. This building would cost too much to be repaired and as it has the inconvenience of being 500 yards away from the school which means lot of walking back and forward to do our work, I believe it would be better to wreck it down and salvage all the lumber we can, to build a machine shed, which is greatly needed and also lot of material such as sinks, toilets, water pipes, radiators and furniture could be used in the new building.

New Father's house required:

So instead of repairing this old house, I would suggest that an addition be added to the Indian Residential School to serve as the Principal's residence and office. The present heating system
of the Indian School could easily take of these additions and it would mean great savings for fuel and labor and would also be more convenient.

Sketch:

For your convenience, I inclose a sketch showing the proposed additions to the Indian School. On the boys' side, full basement 30' x 42' inside measurement; for toilets, urinals, bathrooms, dressing room, special room for the grown up boys and also cloak rooms.

On the first floor right above this basement would be the Fathers' residence on shown on the sketch.

On the girls' side, also full basement, 30'x 42', for toilets, shower baths, dressing rooms with a special room for the grown up girls.

Above would be two class rooms as I have to take the boys' and girls' infirmaries from the second floor to the first to give more room to the Sisters so using one actual class room as a girls' infirmary.

Building Material:

The Indian School is a fireproof building with cement and bricks. I would like very much to have the additions built out of the same material. But as I have been advised by a Meadow Lake contractor, reinforcing steel will hard to get next Summer and also the transportation of bricks would be pretty expensive. (Beauval School being 116 miles north of the end of rail and the roads are in bad conditions with no hope of getting them repaired in the near future. Winter time would be the best time to have some material transported to Beauval, it is cheaper and easier.)

So I would suggest a full cement basement, the height as the rest of the building and for the first floor wooden frame with brick siding, one layer of asbestos paper, one layer of shiplap, rockwool or similar material in the walls and ceiling, 2, 6 studs, with plastered Cyprock inside. The floor could be made of fireproof tiles. The roof gravel and tar. This would make it practically fireproof and quite warm.

I expect to be able to send you the estimates on the cost of labor and material in about ten days time, in order to have the
estimates figured for this coming fiscal year and have the material transported in winter time.

If the sketch is not clear enough, although I am quite busy, I would be prepared to take a trip to Ottawa. In the meantime, I will appreciate an early reply to this request.

Yours very truly,

F. X. Gagnon, O.M.I.
Principal.

Re: Julie Gardiner.

This child Julie Gardiner is a daughter of Ambroise Gardiner and Helene Bouvier, both Halfbreed. Ambroise Gardiner died many years ago and left his widow and few children. Since that, Helene Bouvier married to a treaty Indian Oliver Piwapiskus from Canoe Lake Reserve.

Beauval October 6th., 1934.

Dear Sir,

Re: Louis Vital and Victor Morin.

These three boys whose father and mother are Felix Morin and Angèle Daigneault are of mixed blood and not annuitant but they are "living the Indian mode of life on a reserve" Clear Lake Reserve.

Being also a charge to the said reserve and therefore to the Department, according to the Indian Act., they are eligible for admission to the schools.

It is understood that preference is given to annuitant children and I hope next summer the school will be full with treaty children.

Yours very truly,

To the Deputy Supt. Gen. F. X. Gagnon O.M.I.
of Indian Affairs. Principal.

Ottawa

This child Ernest Durocher is the son of Jimmy Durocher who died many years ago. Since that his wife a halfbreed married a treaty Indian of the name of Johnny Piwapiskus from Canoe Lake Reserve. Therefore this child although not annuitant is eligible for admission to the school, living the Indian mode of life on a reserve and being a charge to the reserve. So, according to your circular November 9th, 1933 this boy is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Hoping these explanations will be satisfactorily,

I am Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon D.M.I.

Principal.

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I am very pleased to tell you that the children are all well, except one girl, who is actually sick with a severe cold, and that they all enjoyed to be in school.

I ask to discharge Raphael Opikokew Register no 23 from Canoe Lake Band no 14, and also Clementine Est'aldhenen no. 2172 from English River Band 22.

The boy was expelled from school on account of his bad character and bad conduct, he was a very bad example for the others.

The girl being pretty near 17 of age had to go and help her mother for house-keeping. Her mother being alone, her other daughter being in school, and also not feeling very well, she need her.

Beauval January 3rd, 1903.

Dear Sir,

He Albert and Eleonore Aubichon.

Please find enclosed the application forms for the admission to this school of Albert and Eleonore Aubichon. Their father and mother are half-breed and therefore not annuitant. But according to your decision in September last, I was authorised to take these children; this was done through our representative in Ottawa, Rev. Father F.A. Mercotte.

Therefore last fall I wrote to their father to advise him that his children were accepted and to bring them. But being away from home the season was too advanced when he got my letter. After that there was no way of communication, so at Christmas he brought his children along after 5 days traveling with dogs sleigh.

So, I could not refuse according to the instructions received last fall and also according to the Indian Act:

"While it was not considered that the children of half-breeds proper to Manitoba and the Prairie Provinces should be admitted into Indian Schools and paid for by the Department, it was conceded that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools...."

As I do not abuse of this act and that preference is always given to treaty children, and considering too that these children are living on the English River reserve, and live the Tehapweyan mode of life are eligible for admission to this school.

Furthermore, their father although...
half-breed claims that he never got the scrips and he is willing to take treaty any time. He already made application Mr. Murison from Regina on his paying treaty trip a year ago last summer, took all the informations about his case and he was promised to be advised, but unfortunately, he never got a word about it.

So, for these reasons, I sincerely believe that these children are children to whom the law applies and therefore eligible to be admitted as grant-earning pupils.

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.

Mr. J. D. Sutherland
For Supt of Indian Education.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant re Victor, Louis, and Vital Morin, I am sure that there is a mistake about the application forms I sent to the Department on November the 8th. These forms were sent only as certificate of Health and not as admission, as all these children were approved by you. Refer file I32-I-IO, October 20th, 1932.

In your file to you will find a letter covering explanation why I asked the admission of these three boys although of mixed blood; they are eligible for admission to schools according to the Indian Act.

Hoping these explanations will be satisfactory I can assure you that I am making special effort to have only Treaty children only. Very likely I will admit a few children at Christmas and next summer I intend to recruit up to Portage La Loche.

Yours very truly,

F. X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

I am just in receipt of your letters of 3rd and the 13th instant about the admission of the new children.

Regarding Joseph Montgrand,

After information I found that his father and mother are both dead and I cannot understand why I wrote that his mother only was dead. Any way it is a fact. For the relation with Gabriel One Eye, his guardian, Father Fenard who was in Portage La Loche for many years, told me that Gabriel One Eye is his cousin, but his wife must be Joseph's aunt.

If this explanation is not satisfactory, please notify me, and I will get from the Father at Portage La Loche. Today, I did not want to wait so long for an answer, because you know yourself where is Portage La Loche.

Hoping this is satisfactory,

I am,

Yours very truly,

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.

Beauval May 21st 1934.

Dear Sir:

I have just on hand your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to that F. Billette 0198. This is due to a mistake made by my secretary. F. Billette died last summer during the Holidays apparently with T.B. at Peter Pound Lake, about 100 miles north from here. It is only in August that I heard about her death and I told my secretary about it, but as her name had to appear on the September Report, my secretary kept her name on the list for the report and also for the December Return by mistake.

Being very busy around New Year's, I did not check the report very closely, unfortunately and on the March return, that name was not on the list.

As we received a grant on the December Return for 92 days after her death, I would ask you to kindly deduct this amount on the next return or if you wish a cheque will be mailed to the Department for this amount. I am very sorry that such a mistake happened and I hope that these explanations will satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

F.X. Gagnon

Ottawa, February 11, 1935.

Right Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, enclosing an amended return for the Beauval Indian Residential School for the quarter ended September 30th, last.

Arrangements are being made to allow the balance which you claim for the September quarter of 1934, but it will not be possible to consider making payments for the other September quarters.

This matter emphasizes the importance of extreme care being taken in preparing the quarterly return. The September quarter return, in particular, should be carefully watched and grant should be requested for each pupil for the actual number of days such pupil is in residence during the September quarter, plus the forty-three (43) days' holidays for which grant is allowed. For instance, if a pupil is allowed home on holidays on July 1st and returns on August 13th, grant should be requested for 92 days. If, however, a pupil allowed home on holidays on July 1st does not return until September 1st, grant should be requested for such pupil for 73 days (30 days in residence during September plus 43 days' holidays). In cases such as the latter, a note should appear opposite the pupil's name in the column provided for that purpose, stating the reasons for the absence.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Re-Approval for Admission.

Dear Sir:

I wish to bring to your attention the following cases and would like you to approve their remaining at the school for another year:

Marguerite Mispumane No.0143; this case was approved on July 26th 1934 (Ref.132-1-10). Marguerite is 18 years old. She is an orphan; both parents dead; no close relations. Good character; she exercises a beneficial influence on others. Last winter, she was ill; she is not yet very strong but is gradually gaining in strength. As she is, she is not in a state to be married; and she would be compelled to do so if she were discharged from the school. We hope the Department will grant her the well-deserved favor of remaining with the Sisters for another year.

Sarraigne MacIntyre No.0159; this case also approved on July 26th 1934 (Ref.132-1-10). Sarraigne is in her 18th year. Very talented girl, serious, of excellent behavior, and inclined to devote herself for the welfare of others. The Principal in accord with the Sisters of the School, hope that later on when she has returned to her reserve, she could be of valuable assistance in post-school activities which they propose to organise and which shall be explained to you later. Another year at our School would enable us to prepare her for this purpose. So, for the sake of our cause, I solicit your permission to keep her, as a special favor for this child of rare endowments.

C. Lariviere, No.0166; 16 years. Good character. She is an orphan, and quite destitute. In these grounds, we request that she remain at school for another year.

M. Piwapiskus No.0135; 16 years old. Good girl; poorly endowed; much room for improvement. No opportunity for early marriage. She also is an orphan. We therefore request that her stay at school be prolonged another year.

P. Grandfather No.0193; 16 years old. Good moral character as shown by previous reports. Not ready for married life, because of a state of general weakness, which is steadily improving. Another year at school would be very beneficial to her, and we trust the Department will grant us this.

M. Doré No.0195; 16 years old. She has attended school very little on account of ill health. But now, according to the Doctor's testimony she is in a state to attend, and would greatly benefit by another year at school.

Awaiting a favorable reply to these requests, we beg to remain

Yours respectfully,

Mr. S.L.Macdonald,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

Ottawa, April 14, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir:

Referring to conversation with Your Lordship during your recent visit to the Department, regarding the age limit for the discharge of those boys who are 14 years of age from the residential schools conducted under our auspices, in order that they can be returned to their parents, to acquire a knowledge of hunting, trapping, etc., I have to say that this meets with the approval of the Department. The Indian Agents at The Pas, Norway House, and Battleford are being informed and requested to advise the Principals of the Guy, Cross Lake and Beauval Indian Residential Schools accordingly.

It is not intended that all the boys, upon attaining 14 years of age shall be granted discharge, but only those cases which the Principals consider to be in sufficiently good health to accompany their parents on their hunting and trapping trips. It is thought that Indian boys should have acquired sufficient education for their future needs by the time they reach 14 years of age and that it would be to their future advantage to acquire a knowledge of hunting and trapping, on which their future livelihood will, to a great extent, depend.

I would suggest that Your Lordship discuss the matter with the Principals of the above named schools and advise them that careful selection should be made by them of the boys whose discharge they would recommend at 14 years of age.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Right Rev. M. LaJeunesse, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Keewatin,
The Pas, Man.
Ottawa, April 14, 1936.

Dear Sir:

His Lordship Bishop Lajeunesse, during a recent visit to the Department, discussed the matter of the age limit for the discharge of the boys from the Indian Residential Schools conducted under his auspices. He recommended that those boys who are in good health should be given their discharge when they reach 14 years of age, in order that they can be returned to their parents or guardians, with a view to acquiring a knowledge of hunting and trapping, which will be the main source of their future livelihood.

The Department considers that it would be in the interests of the boys to be granted their discharge at 14 years of age, as they should by that time have acquired an education sufficient to meet their future needs. You may, therefore, inform the Principal of the Beauval Indian Residential School that, when he considers that a boy, upon attaining his fourteenth birthday, should receive his discharge, he should make application to the Department, through your office, in the usual manner.

It is not intended that all boys upon reaching 14 years of age are to be discharged, but, as stated, only those who are in sufficiently healthy condition to accompany their parents or guardians in order to acquire a knowledge of hunting, trapping, etc.

I would request that you advise the Principal accordingly.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

Dear Father,

Per your request with the quarterly School returns for December, I have attempted to fill in the numbers or Band number, where omitted and the following is the result.

0201, J.Gardiner, Canoe Lake, we have no Indian of this name on our records.

0206, E.Aubichon, English River, no such name on our records.

0204, Clara Yamaleg English River, this is #104.

In this case, you show Pupil 0239, as No.104 English river as there is no Marguerite or others in this Band named LaLibertie, I think No.0239, should be Marguerite,Darazale No.6 English River.

26, E Morin, P.P.L, we have no Indian by the name of Morin at Fortage La Loche.

53 A Stevenson, this boy is From No.20 Water Hen Lake and not Meadow Lake

60 Albert Kokan, there has never been any application for this boys admission and one should be completed as required by the Dept as he is evidently not of this Agency, his Band and Treaty Number should be obtained from his parents Treaty Ticket.

62 Not Known and we have no such name on our records.

67 Is from No.15 Water Hen Lake, not Meadow Lake.

Many of the difficulties as above are through change of names and the pupils should always be put on the Rolls in the name in which the Application was approved, as many, have trade names, church Names and Treaty Names and unless the Number is taken from their Ticket, when application is made, it is in many cases almost impossible to trace them.

Many of the above are evidently before my time or yours and I have no records to trace them by or account for the names.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

✓ 0176 - J. D. Naurayé died, report on death forwarded.
✓ 0189 - O. Diazere died, report on death forwarded.
✓ 0193 - P. Grandifrançais had reached the age limit.
✓ 0206 - E. Aubichon was needed at home.
✓ 0222 - M. T. Piwaniskus died, report on death forwarded.
✓ 0237 - M. B. Piwaniskus; died, report forwarded.
13 - Francis Bell; had reached age limit.
37 - L. Mongrand; died, report forwarded.
56 - Emil Nezaroche;
61 - P. Nezaroche;
62 - M. Nikotase;
65 - L. Detcheldakodhi;
0208 - L. S. Opikokew;
0239 - Marguerite Laliberté, and no. 64, John Gunn, are both listed in the report, as my copy shows.

I am sorry that the June report was unsatisfactory. But I had thought that, as far as the pupils who had died were concerned, the report which Dr. Laviole forwarded to the department on their deaths would be a notice of their discharge from the school. On receipt of your letter I made a special trip to Isle a La Crosse and ascertained from the Doctor that these reports had been forwarded. As for pupil no. 0193 P. Grandifrançais, 0206 E. Aubichon, and 13-Francis Bell, application for their discharge was not sent in due to a mistake of my clerk, since I thought it had gone in after the March report, as I had instructed at that time.

I enclose discharge forms covering these pupils who have died or been dismissed. I would appreciate information as to whether this is the proper procedure in case of death of pupils.

I trust this explanation is wholly satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

V. Bleau, o.m.i.

"This year, I have two girls of sixteen years of age that I would like to keep in school for the following reasons:

0173 Cecile Estaldhenen 16 years old is neglected child, having nobody to take care of her. So, if discharged, it will mean a great detriment to the girl, while in school she is learning very good and also she is a good example to the other girls.

The Department has received accounts showing that you expended an amount of $1042.30 in transporting children to and from the Guy residential school during the past summer. Very careful consideration was given to this account and although we had previously decided to only allow $200.00 I agreed with Rev. J.O. Flourde, O.M.I., that an amount of $250.00 would be paid. A cheque for the latter amount will go forward.

While the Department is only paying a portion of the expense incurred we are concerned with the very heavy amount expended for transportation as shown by your letter. In the interests of both the school management and ourselves it is desirable to keep all expenditures as low as possible. This is especially true at the present time due to conditions of which you are aware and which make the future rather uncertain.

Is there no other method of transporting the children which would reduce the expenditure by a substantial amount? It is felt that the parents should be sufficiently interested to come to the school and take their children home for holidays. It is realized, of course, that it might be necessary to incur an expenditure for returning them to the school. As intimated above it is doubtful what amount the Department will be able to allow next year for transportation costs. It is, therefore, necessary that all Principals should give this matter very serious thought. Children from more distant Reserves might be kept at the school all summer unless the parents are sufficiently interested to come to the school and take the children home without cost. I should appreciate hearing from you when you have had an opportunity of reviewing the whole situation.

Yours truly,

Rev. F.K. Gagnon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Beauval, Sask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Beauval Sask., Jan. 22 1940.

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th ultimo, regarding the transportation of children to and from the school and I take this opportunity to thank you for the kind interest shown to the school in sending a cheque to the amount of $250.00, which is very appreciated.

At the same time, I am pleased to assure you that the transporting expenditure will be reduced next summer and I expect to reduce it more before a couple years.

At present, I believe it is almost impossible to change the transporting method of children, as, no doubt, you are aware that the Indians of the North do not yet understand the benefit of education as well as their brothers living in the prairies and too radical a change would mean that these Indian children will be without education.

Furthermore, the Indians do not have the proper equipment to undertake such a trip on big lakes and I am of the opinion that it would cost the school more by feeding or supplying the Indians with provisions for the return trip than the present system, which saves me lot of trouble.

As already mentioned, this I expect to save on the amount as well as on the cost of fuel by using a new kind of motor on my barge. By using Bishop Breynat's plane I will also reduce the cost of air transporting of children.

And likely, this season will be the time, I need a plane for this purpose as new roads actually under construction will permit to adopt a cheaper way of transporting the children.

For this year, I would be satisfied to receive the same amount as last year for this purpose.

Yours very truly,

F. X. Gagnon O.M.I.

Mr. Philip Phelan.
Chief, Training Division.

February 1, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo with reference to the cost of transporting children to and from the Beauval Indian Residential School.

It is noted that you hope to reduce the expenditure for this service but that for the year 1940 you will be satisfied to receive the same amount as last year; namely, $250.00.

Your request will be kept in mind but at the present time I am not in a position to state whether or not such an amount can be allowed. Due to present conditions it is inevitable that our appropriation will be reduced and consequently matters have reached a stage where everyone interested in Indian education must do everything possible to reduce expenditure. The question of funds at our disposal for the fiscal year 1940-41 is still further complicated at the present time on account of the recent dissolution of Parliament and it will be several months before we will be in a position to definitely state what amount will be available for transportation during the summer of 1940. You will, therefore, see the necessity for making immediate plans to have the children transported free of cost as far as possible.

Yours truly,

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of January 22 and my reply of February 1 with reference to the cost of transporting children to and from the Beauval Indian Residential School.

There has been a drastic reduction in our appropriation and consequently for the summer of 1940 we will be unable to allow at the Beauval School a larger amount than $125.00 for the transportation of pupils. As pointed out in my letter of February 1 you should make plans as soon as possible to have the children transported free of cost.

Dear Sir,

I am just back from the North to pick up the children to school, as usual, I have encountered many difficulties. First of all, I had made arrangements with the C.P.R. Air Line to bring the children from White Fish and La Loche. In the meantime, the company has closed Prince Albert Air Base. So these children could not be transported.

At the other points some parents have been kicking about the school, complaining about a few things, but in all this I found out that those who were complaining did not want to let their children go to school.

With all the expenses occurred in this trip I have only 60 children in school. I expect a few more at a later date. The Indians are showing great indifference towards the school, or they do not force their children to go to school. In other words, the children are their own masters. If they want to go to school, it is alright, if not, it is still all right with them. Most of the time, just at the time, that a child would start to learn something, they do not send him back to school. Thus, the Branch is spending money for very little result.

So on account of this, I believe that something should be done to put in force the Indian Act regarding compulsory attendance. I am sure if this would be done once or twice, there would not be any more difficulties about recruiting children in the future. So I wish you could do something in that line.

I am enclosing a list of pupils that are not coming back to school and also of those who are of school age to help you.

Before making any attempt to get the children from La Loche I will wait for an answer. So I do not make any useless expenses.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) P.E. Gagnon, O.M.I.
Dear Sir,

As the area covered by this school takes in a large territory, I would not be in favour of going to any great expense in compelling children to attend. However, I am leaving the matter in your hands so what action you would suggest should be taken.

Ottawa, September 11, 1942.

Re: Irregularity of Attendance -
Beauval Residential School

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 3rd instant and also copy of a communication relating to the marginally-noted subject, received by you from the Reverend Father Gagnon.

It is scarcely possible to overemphasize the importance of having the accommodation provided at our residential schools occupied to the fullest extent in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves. It is important, also, that the average pupil's course of study should not be interrupted until he has gained mastery of the subjects to which he has been devoting his attention. It is a sheer waste of human energy and money to permit an Indian pupil to attend school for three or four years and then allow him to abandon his studies and proceed to forget everything he has learned. The Department is aware, of course, that there is this year acute labour shortage in the province of Saskatchewan and that 't may be difficult to arrange for the return of the senior pupils on the first of September. However, we are anxious that you should do everything humanly possible to assist the Principal in securing his full quota of pupils. If Indian parents are deliberately ignoring the appeals that have been made to them from time to time to encourage their children to attend school, the desirability of imposing the penalties for which provision has been made in the Act should be carefully considered. The Department will be governed largely by your recommendations.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

October 31, 1944.

Dear Father Gagnon:

We have received several letters from the Reverend Principal of the Thunderchild Residential School protesting strongly against the admission of six children named Macallum to your school. It appears that these children were regularly enrolled at the Thunderchild School and were allowed home on holidays and, instead of returning to Thunderchild, they went to Beauval. I feel certain that you were not fully informed of all the circumstances, or you would not have accepted them at Beauval. I think you will agree that it is impossible to handle admissions to Indian schools if parents, instead of returning children to the school where they were enrolled, place them in some other institution. Certainly it has not been our practice to sanction such methods. Under the circumstances it would be appreciated if you would return the children to the Thunderchild School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

The Police at Ilia a la Crosse has been drawing my attention on new regulations regarding boats as to the number of articles that would be needed for the transportation of the school children from and to the school.

Here is the list:

1 Approved Lifebuoy,
1 Approved Life Jacket of each on board. If more than 12 passengers are carried approved buoyant apparatus is needed sufficient to accommodate 50% of the number of persons on board.
2 Fire Buckets,
2 Tetrachloride Extinguishers of 1 ½ quarts Cap. of the hand pump type.
1 Extinguisher 2 gall cap. to discharge froth.

Could ask the Department to procure these articles and have them sent in time for the 15th of June if these articles are available at all now. If not, could get a special permit from the police until these articles can be procured.

Beauval Sask., May 1 1945.

Mr. C.L. Bell,
Acting Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.,

Dear Sir:

The only girl that is of age to be discharged this year is no 0224 Marie Opikokew.

As she is doing fine at school and could learn some more yet, I would kindly ask the Department to keep her in school for one more year or until she get married.

The reason is that her father has a fairly big family to support and for one reason or another does seem to be able to support them properly. The children therefore showing propensity to T.B.

So by staying in school where she will receive proper care she will be in a position to overcome this propensity.

Yours very truly,

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Health & Welfare, Ottawa.

Dear Dr. Moore:

Re Mrs. Stanley Matchee #83 Meadow Lake.

The above mentioned woman was examined at the T.B. Clinic Meadow Lake and found to be in an advanced condition of T.B.

I have since seen this woman and have arranged to send her to the San. as soon as possible. She has a family of five children running from an infant to a boy of fourteen.

The two eldest children are enrolled in Thunderchild Residential School and the third child is almost of school age.

In order to help her in getting to the San. and arranging family matters I would recommend the following:
1. That John Baptiste aged 14 be discharged from Thunderchild Residential School. He is a big boy for his age and is needed to help his Father.
2. The boy Joseph aged 11 be transferred from Thunderchild Residential School to Beauval Residential School where he would be a companion for his brother Stanley aged 5 whom the parents desire to place in Beauval.
3. The two younger children we are placing with reliable Indians on the Reserve.

For the sake of the children and the other Indians this woman should get to the San. as soon as possible and I took it upon myself to suggest to the Farm Instructor on Meadow Lake that he send Joseph and Stanley to Beauval, when they were around gathering the other children for that school.

The health of all concerned is of more importance than the question of which school the children are to attend.

P.W. Head M.D.
Medical Superintendent.

Mr. C.S. Bell, Indian Agent, BATTLEFORD, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Beauval Residential School:

Tobie Jos. Lemaigre Donald Fiddler
Ernest Thos. Lemaigre Albert Fiddler
Ovide Wolverine

You also forwarded the application for Sarazine Wolverine. Our records show that this girl was originally admitted to the Beauval School on Aug. 14, 1936. Her name appeared on subsequent returns until June, 1945. She was not shown on the return for the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1945, nor on subsequent returns although no application was received for her discharge. It is presumed that she was allowed out of school for some reason and at the present time has been re-admitted. On future returns she should have the same register number as previously, namely 0232.

You should point out to the Principal that each quarter return should be accompanied by a copy of Form I.A. 411 giving information regarding the pupils admitted and discharged during the quarter. Pupils' names should not be removed from the return until the Department has approved the discharge.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
